Title: Priyanka sends grains to Lko for distribution on Ambedkar Jayanti
Article:
Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra has sent ration to be distributed to the needy in Lucknow on Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar’s birth anniversary on Tuesday..

In a statement, UP Congress chief Ajay Kumar Lallu said that Priyanka sent a truck load of ration to Lucknow so that needy people could be provided foodgrains.

He said that the Congress leader had been overseeing relief work from the beginning not only in Uttar Pradesh, but across the country.

Lallu said that community kitchens were being run by Congress workers in numerous places in the state, including Lucknow.

“We are providing ration to the needy wherever we are getting information. Party workers are working hard to serve the people in the state,” he said.

The UPCC chief also wrote a letter to Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath expressing concern over the harassment of Congress workers and leaders engaged in distribution of lunch packets, food grains and other help to the needy.

He appealed to the chief minister to direct administrative officers not to harass those coming forward to help the needy in this hour of crisis.

Title: Wheat procurement to start tomorrow
Article:
|

Amidst relaxation from lockdown, wheat procurement by government agencies would start across the state from April 15.

The state government has however imposed conditions for enforcing norms of social distancing at procurement centres to prevent spread of coronavirus.

Wheat procurement was earlier scheduled to start from April 1 and end on June 15 but it was postponed to April 15 due to the lockdown.

The UP government has set an ambitious wheat procurement target of 55 lakh MT for the 2020-21 Rabi marketing season.

Government agencies would procure wheat at the rate of Rs 1,925 per quintal, which is the minimum support price.

Despite unseasonal rains and hailstorm this year, Rabi crop has recorded a bumper yield and farmers need the support of official procurement agencies to purchase their agricultural produce.

If the procurement targets are met then it is likely to infuse over Rs 11,000 crore in rural economy, a big boost for the sagging economy.

During the last Rabi season, the state had failed to achieve its target and could log only about 38 lakh MT of wheat as compared to the target of 55 Lakh MT.

Sluggish procurement in 2019-20 Rabi season was attributed to Lok Sabha elections apart from competitive prices in open market.

Following the poor response last year, the government extended wheat procurement window by an additional 10 days to June 25, 2019 to partly achieve its target and keep wheat prices firm in the market to benefit farmers.

Of the target of 55 lakh MT, Food Corporation of India (FCI) will procure 1.5 lakh MT, while the remaining would be purchased by various state government agencies. For this 5,000 procurement centres across UP have been set up. The bulk of 25 lakh MT and 5 lakh MT would be procured by UP Cooperative Federation Limited (UPCFL) which will run 2,516 centres and UP Cooperative Union (UPCU) with 321 centres respectively. The FCI will operate 94 centres and Food department will operate 715 centres.

Title: BJP leader held for bootlegging
Article:
|

Yet another Bharatiya Janata Party leader embarrassed the party brass when a raid exposed his home-run bootlegging operations during lockdown in Jaunpur on Sunday.

The police arrested the erring BJP leader and his kin.

It was alleged that police and excise officials were in cahoots with him in running the illegal operation and ignored several complaints made by locals.

It was only after a complaint was made to ADM (Finance and Revenue) Ram Prakash that cognisance was taken and police and excise officials raided the house.

To cover up his operations, the accused had put up a board of ‘Guru Singh Sabha’ and organised langar (community feast) for the poor outside his house.

As per reports, residents of Kesari Bazaar Punjabi Market in Kotwali police station area found that BJP’s minority cell secretary Manish Sethi and his family were making money by selling liquor for a premium from their house.

The sale of liquor has been banned during lockdown.

After initial complaints failed to stir the lower rung administration, they complained to ADM (F&R) after which a raid was conducted at Sethi’s place on Sunday and three boxes of liquor were recovered.

Subsequently, Manish Sethi, his wife Chhaya and son Anand were arrested.

After the arrests, some local BJP leaders tried to exert pressure on officials to release him but the locals converged on the spot and put a spanner in their plans.

Title: BJP govt pursuing vendetta politics, alleges Akhilesh
Article:
|

Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav lashed out at the Bharatiya Janata Party government in Uttar Pradesh, accusing it of pursuing vendetta politics against SP workers running relief operations in districts.

Akhilesh said that the police registered FIR against Samajwadi Party workers for “committing the crime of distributing food and other relief material to the people in distress”.

He said, “SP workers are being booked by the BJP government for distributing ration and helping people in this hour of crisis. This is inhuman and condemnable.”

“Daily review of relief work by top echelons of the government will make no material change at ground level. The chief minister and Team 11 will have to establish direct contact with people on the streets. Officials should go to areas inhibited by the poor and make on-spot verification of relief work done by government agencies,” the SP chief said in a release issued in Lucknow on Monday.

Title: Corona suspects flee shelter homes due to hunger in Bulandshahr
Article:
The Bulandshahr administrative officers went into a tizzy after 16 coronavirus suspects quarantined at Janata Inter College in Dibai were found missing on Sunday afternoon.

Fourteen of them, however, returned after some time and when quizzed, made the shocking disclosure that they escaped as they were not getting adequate food there.

However, the district administration denied the charge and said that they were looking for the two missing suspects.

Senior Superintendent of Police Santosh Kumar Singh said that 103 people were put in quarantine at the centre in Dibai and 16 of them broke the window grill on Saturday night and escaped.

Their disappearance came to light on Sunday afternoon and a case was registered.

None of the escapees have so far tested positive for coronavirus.

Meanwhile, an FIR was registered against six persons, including two assistant development officers posted at Dibai block, for negligence in disaster management and disobeying administrative orders during lockdown in Bulandshahr.

District Magistrate Ravindra Kumar said that during inspection of three quarantine homes in Dibai on Sunday, ADO Abhilash Batham and Suresh Chand Arya, gram panchayat secretary Jai Pal Singh, Mohit Bhushan, Nrip Singh, Kripal Singh and gram development officer were found not following orders and giving false information and ignoring lockdown and quarantine rules.

Meanwhile in Moradabad, three areas were sealed after being declared as high-risk zones on Monday.

Karula area with dense population was sealed completely after a coronavirus positive case was found there. Besides, Galshaheed, Mughalpura and Nagphani areas were also sealed after being declared high-risk zones.

A Delhi University student and a native of Karula area returned after attending Nizamuddin markaz meet on March 19 and his location was ascertained through a list obtained from Delhi police. After this, he was quarantined at MIT guest house from April 8.

He had been living in a Delhi apartment after classes were suspended from March 8 and he visited Nizamuddin on March 8-9 and later returned to Karula but did not ensure social distancing in his house. Besides, he met several friends too.

His report came in on Sunday in which he was found to be coronavirus positive.

Chief Medical Officer Dr MC Garg said that everyone was alerted after the positive report and the student’s parents, two brothers, a sister, a sister-in-law and three other minors were isolated and their samples were taken.

Nodal Officer for COVID-19 in Moradabad, Dr Dinesh Kumar Premi said that the area and their house had been sanitised.

“Health department officials have collected inputs about his friends and two teams will contact them and they will be quarantined,” he said.

Title: Development works all set to start with safety measures
Article:
Pending development works across the state would be started by ensuring social distancing after the first phase of the lockdown concludes on Tuesday.

This was decided in a meeting attended by ministers and top officials of construction-related departments and chaired by Deputy Chief Minster Keshav Prasad Maurya on Monday.

Giving guidelines to officials on ensuring social distancing, Maurya asked the officials at Vishveshariya Bhawan to sanitise machines and gadgets used on sites to prevent spread of coronavirus.

He gave clearance for restarting the work on Purvanchal Expressway, Bundelkhand Expressway, Gorakhpur Link Expressway and other projects taken up by the Yogi Adityanath government.

Maurya directed that local authorities to ensure that workers and their kin got proper and nutritious food.

“Where residential facilities cannot be provided to workers at construction sites, measures should be taken to keep them in nearby places and ensure hygiene and social distancing,” Maurya said.

UP Expressways Industrial Development Authority (UPEIDA) Chief Executive Officer Awanish Awasthi said that adequate material and work force were available to restart work on these projects.

It was decided to divide the work separately so that proper sanitisation and social distancing could be maintained.

“If desilting of canal has to be taken up for 500 metres, then work should be divided into 100 metre segments so that social distancing could be ensured. Likewise, work should be first started at the place where labourers stay at the same place. Besides expressways, works relating to highways, railway over bridges (RoB), and various other projects would also be taken up,” he said.

Besides Maurya, Jal Shakti Minister Mahendra Singh, Rural Engineering Minister Brajesh Pathak, Urban Development Minister Ashutosh Tandon along with heads and incharges of Nirman Nigam, Bridge Corporation, Jal Nigam, Rural Engineering, UPEIDA, PWD and other departmental chiefs and senior officers attended the meeting.

The deputy chief minister also inspected the community kitchens run by the Public Works Department and directed officials to ensure cleanliness and hygiene while preparing and giving food packets to the needy. He also lauded the efforts of PWD officials in this direction.

Title: CM: Admn to be responsible if corona suspects found hiding
Article:
|

Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath warned district officials that they would be held accountable and punished if people who avoided COVID-19 test and were hiding from police were found in religious places or houses.

“People with symptoms of coronavirus infection should come forward and report to officials, else stern action will be taken against them if they are identified by the administration. This is the responsibility of district officials to ensure no one hides in religious places,” Yogi said during a meeting with Team-11 in Lucknow on Monday.

The direction is aimed at the missing members of Tablighi Jamaat, some of whom have avoided coronavirus tests and were found hiding in mosques and madarasas. Of 550 cases reported in the state so far, 307 are related to Jamaat members.

The chief minister said that all positive cases of coronavirus in the state were in the hotspot areas. “Now, if a new case other than those in hotspots is traced, then it will be considered as negligence of district administration officials and they will face action,” he said.

A total of 146 coronavirus hotspots have been demarcated by the state government in 15 districts so far. Initially the number was 102 but it went up as new cases came to light.

These hotspots have 1.71 lakh houses and are inhabited by 9.78 lakh people. So far, 401 coronavirus positive cases have been reported from these hotspots and orders have been issued to sanitise these areas.

Besides, every district magistrate have marked hotspots in their respective districts and their numbers have also increased.

Yogi Adityanath complimented the Pilibhit district administration after it became the first district in the state to be declared coronavirus free. There were two COVID-19 patients in Pilibhit, and both have recovered after treatment. There has been no new case in Pilibhit since then.

Additional Chief Secretary (Home) Awanish Awasthi told media persons on Monday that sanitisation and doorstep delivery were being done in a big way across the state so that people did not suffer due to shortage of essentials.

Awasthi said the chief minister had directed Industry and MSME departments to look into opportunities to attract industrial houses to invest in the state as several big companies had announced to shift their units from China.

“It will be a big opportunity for the state to rope in these companies and help them relocate their units from China to UP,” he said.

In another important development, the government decided that people who were quarantined in shelter home in the district of their village could be sent to their homes after medical check-up. However, people from other districts and states would have to stay in the shelter homes till the completion of their isolation.

The additional chief secretary said that the chief minister had appealed to people to download Arogya Setu app to keep abreast about coronavirus infection, incidence and related information. The app has been downloaded by 40 lakh people in UP so far.

Title: COVID-19 cases in Delhi rise to 1,578; death toll 32
Article:
The number of coronavirus cases in the national capital on Wednesday increased to 1,578, with 17 fresh cases and two deaths being reported, according to Delhi government authorities.

The death toll from COVID-19 in Delhi now stands at 32.

Of the total cases, 1,080 are those who have been brought to facilities through special operations.

Government authorities had in March carried out measures to quarantine people linked to a religious congregation held in south Delhi's Nizamuddin area earlier in the month.

By Tuesday night, the number of cases of the deadly virus in the city stood at 1,561, including 30 deaths.

Out of the total 1,578 patients, 40 have been discharged and one has migrated out of the country, the authorities said.

Title: A blessing for all
Article:
At a time when healthcare-related information can mean the difference between life and death, DD’s programme Kalyani was a trailblazer in its communication strategies

Once, when there was no electricity in a village in Odisha, there was a scramble to get batteries to generate power, so that the whole community could watch its favourite television programme. No, it wasn’t Big Boss that the villagers wanted to see. Neither was it any of the popular serials or music and dance reality shows. It was Kalyani , a pioneering health programme broadcast by Doordarshan (DD) to raise awareness about preventable ailments like malaria, tuberculosis, water-borne and tobacco-related diseases and iodine deficiency disorders. The programme also featured episodes on leprosy, blindness, cancer, HIV/AIDS, sexual and reproductive health.

First broadcast in May 2002, Kalyani ran for 10 years in nine States, making it the longest-running health communication initiative not just in the country but also globally. However, in April 2012, this bi-weekly show was discontinued and replaced by Swasth Bharat, a similar health programme. However, Swasth Bharat has not struck the same chord with the people as Kalyani did.

At a time when healthcare-related information can mean the difference between life and death, Kalyani was a trailblazer in its communication strategies. Even today, chloroquine tablets promoted by the programme as a measure against malaria are better known as “Kalyani tablets” in many villages in Madhya Pradesh, thanks to the popularity of the programme and the awareness it created on the mosquito-borne disease.

Though it may seem unbelievable but Kalyani even garnered profits and TRPs equivalent to news programmes. It also won prestigious international awards, including the Gates Foundation Award for malaria, Asian Media Information and Communication Centre (for the best communication strategy on HIV/AIDS) and the Rose d’Or, popularly known as the television Oscars for its effective health communication.

A brainchild of DD’s Development Communication Division (DCD), the programme was produced in partnership with the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and the National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO). Broadcast on Mondays and Thursdays from 6.30 to 7 pm, the half-hour programme was strategically broken into different segments to include quiz competitions, phone-ins, panel discussions with doctors as well as real life stories. With a catchy title song composed by popular music composers Jatin-Lalit, penned by eminent lyricist Naqsh Lyalpuri and sung by famed singer Kavita Krishnamurty, the programme reached out to thousands in the nine States where health indicators were poor. These States included Assam, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh, Odisha, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh (UP) and Uttarakhand.

In Kunra, a small village in Raipur district of Chhattisgarh, a group of women were so inspired by Kalyani that they decided to get together to spread awareness in their village. But they didn’t know how to go about it. So they approached the producer of the programme who suggested the idea of forming a “Kalyani club” that would carry forward and implement Kalyani’s messages on health. Within four years of the institution of the club, awareness about HIV/AIDS became so widespread that even schoolchildren in the village knew the different modes of transmission. The women dovetailed information on HIV/AIDS with information on other health programmes like diarrhoea, a major childhood illness in the village (and State), malaria, tuberculosis and reproductive health problems.

But first the Kalyani club members discussed these diseases among themselves to ensure that they were well-informed about them. Then the women went from door-to-door to disseminate information about the diseases. By packaging information about HIV/AIDS with other infections, they were able to bring down cases of malaria and reproductive tract infections (RTI) and ensure special care for pregnant and lactating mothers.

When women of neighbouring villages heard about how the club had engendered development and improved health indicators, they were galvanised into forming similar clubs of their own. Consequently, over 300 clubs, each with a membership of at least 25 women, were formed in 16 districts of Chhattisgarh.

The clubs became an integral part of the lives of women. According to Usha Bhasin, then DCD head, the objective of forming Kalyani clubs was to give a platform to women, particularly those who had never stepped out of their homes, to participate in the process of development. This way the gender component was also integrated in the communications strategy. It also meant dedicated partners in the field to keep hammering the health messages home to ensure their sustainability and total recall. This is exactly what the women of the Kalyani clubs did in their own innovative ways. One such novel tactic adopted by Sunita Vishwakarma, president of Kalyani club in village Raveli in district Durg, was to get the health messages printed on the cover of ration cards. Her rationale was that since all club members were housewives like her and used ration cards, it would be a simple and effective way of getting everyone in the house to see the messages. But Vishwakarma did not stop at ration cards. Having heard on the Kalyani programme that her district had the highest prevalence of HIV in the State, her club members knew they had to stop families from following the traditional practice of tattooing. They knew it would be difficult but they went door-to-door explaining how HIV could be transmitted through unsterilised needles used for tattooing. It took several months and repeated visits before the practice completely stopped.

Data showed that three years after the programme was launched, there was rise in the percentage of women who had heard about AIDS as well as those who knew condoms could reduce chances of getting it. Additionally, more pregnant women began to avail of facilities at hospitals for deliveries. This was a big change, as earlier women used cow dung water to induce labour pain and give birth at home.

After the women of Kalyani clubs got into action, this practice came down and the increase in institutional deliveries helped to reduce maternal mortality and infant mortality.

Although the entire credit for these improvements does not go to Kalyani clubs, some part of it can be attributed to them. This was because at least one member of the Kalyani club was a mitanin (community health worker). This was an integral part of the strategy to enable these clubs to provide health services. In villages where there were no mitanins, the club selected one member for training. This way their credibility as well as skills increased.

The local woman sarpanch (head) and anganwadi (rural child care centre) workers also become members of the Kalyani clubs and this added to their clout.

Thousands of Kalyani clubs formed across these nine States, where the programmes were produced and broadcast, strengthening the Kalyani programmes further.

It was the huge network of Kalyani clubs that translated the words of the programmes into action and brought health and sanitation to these villages. Roads were swept by the community, ponds cleaned of garbage and even a primary healthcare centre, that had remained closed because it was in a Naxal-infested area of Jharkhand, reopened.

In village Kandarka, Kalyani club members were seen as equivalent to medical doctors. When 24-year-old Deepmala was in a dilemma whether to ask her husband to use condoms or not, she sought the advice of Kalyani club members. Dhaneshwari Thakur, 21, an agricultural labourer in Raveli village said that if it wasn’t for the persistence of Kalyani club members who ensured timely vaccinations during his wife’s second pregnancy, she may not have been able to deliver a healthy child. In fact, several newborn girls were christened Kalyani and as the name denotes, they were seen as a blessing or a benediction.

During the time the 3,000 Kalyani clubs were active in the nine States, the percentage of fully immunised children doubled. The number of children (under three years) breast-fed within one hour of birth also registered an increase. In a country where pneumonia, diarrhoea and low birth weight kill hundreds of children every day, informed Kalyani clubs were able to make a difference thanks to the well thought out messages shared by the health programme.

Their success also underlined the importance of putting people at the centre of health communications and engaging their active participation and ownership, something which is lacking in the present milieu.

(The writer is a senior journalist)

Title: We need all hands on deck
Article:
There are no longer allopaths, homeopaths or ayurveds. They are just people with varying levels of competence in medicine that we need

A lot is known about increasing immunity with homeopathy. However, there is some evidence of homeopathic prophylaxis and treatment against infectious diseases. Historically, homeopathy was used to treat and protect against scarlet fever by its founder, Dr Samuel Hahnemann. It was also famously used during the Spanish flu epidemic after World War-I. In fact, Dr Marino published research about homeopathic prophylaxis against swine flu and dengue in 2008 and 2009. One of the most important pieces of research in recent memory is the prophylactic effect of homeopathic medicines on a disease called leptospirosis (is a bacterial infection that humans contract from animals) in Cuba, published in 2010. A whopping 2.3 million Cubans were provided homeopathic prophylaxis and a much lower than expected incidence of the infection occurred that year.

It is irresponsible to suggest that the cure or vaccine for COVID-19 lies with homeopathy. However, at a time when conventional medicine is clutching at straws to treat patients, homeopathy should also be considered. Awareness of the high safety profile of homeopathy, absence of any adverse interactions with conventional medicines and ease of administration should mitigate all reservations regarding deploying homeopathy. This system has anecdotally demonstrated positive therapeutic effects in cases of dengue, swine flu and SARS. Sometimes homeopaths are called in extremely advanced and life-threatening stages of these viral infections which were novel until recently. These are the points which should inform decisions regarding the use of homeopathy for COVID-19.

This is a seminal time for the national health services. Countries are grappling with the possibility or reality of an overwhelmed healthcare system. In England, final year students of medicine and nursing are being graduated as doctors and nurses respectively. A call for 2,50,000 volunteers has been made and vehemently answered, to assist in the national effort against COVID-19. In the US, all manufacturers who can, are being asked to make medical devices and personal protection equipment (PPE). All forms of medical practitioners are being asked to help in emergency rooms of hospitals. Retired doctors and nurses are being asked to report to hospitals. Families are sewing masks at home and sending them to healthcare centres. In the face of paucity, doctors and nurses are using garbage bags as PPE. Every resource which can be made available for the delivery of healthcare is being commandeered in every COVID-hit country.

The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) recently published models to predict the possible number of COVID-19 cases. According to this, 26 per cent of the Indian population may be infected and one in 450 infected individuals may die. This means roughly 35.78 crore Indians may be infected and about 7.9 lakh may die. An article by Brookings India estimates that the number and distribution of hospital beds in India is woefully inadequate and disproportionately distributed for the population it serves. Uttar Pradesh (UP) and other densely-populated States have lower than the national average of Government hospital beds. Therefore, they may not be available everywhere. If every single Government hospital bed is utilised for COVID-19 (which is not possible), India will still not be able to hospitalise even the numbers expected to die of the disease.

The sea of patients who will need clinical examination, detailed history-taking, testing, follow-up care and many other auxiliary measures just to identify a substantial fraction of true cases cannot be handled by Government-run hospitals and doctors alone. The private healthcare infrastructure has been roped in. Steps have been taken to ramp up isolation wards and beds towards this end. Every single nurse, laboratory technician, operation theatre technician, doctor, registered medical practitioner, paramedic and anyone with some basic training in the medical sciences will need to be called upon to do their bit. Recently, the health Ministry roped in Accredited Social Health Activists (ASHA), anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwives (ANMs) and this added 39 lakh pairs of hands to the effort.

India possesses a unique army of doctors in its alternative systems of medicine. The Prime Minister held a meeting with AYUSH practitioners on COVID-19 but not much has come of it. Homeopaths and Ayurvedic practitioners are trained in most subjects taught to students of conventional medicine. They are also trained to conduct a detailed clinical examination of patients and do so daily. If enlisted in the fight against COVID-19, they will require no additional training, save for being kept informed of evolving guidelines for case identification, evaluation and referral.

Senior practitioners of homeopathy occupy a position of influence in the society they serve. Roping them in and using their positions as thought leaders may increase compliance of public health measures. Shedding any biases that may be at play, the health Ministry should rope in all practitioners under the Ministry of AYUSH with expedience. This can add 7.9 lakh trained healthcare workers. Homeopathy and Ayurveda have central councils and State boards. Guidelines, directions and deployment instructions can be communicated through these channels.

There are no longer allopaths, homeopaths, ayurveds or nurses. They are simply individuals with varying levels of competence in medicine. At a time where citizens are being asked to give up their livelihood and continue an incarcerated existence, there will be few who will refuse a call to help in mitigating the impact that this disease may have on our nation.

(The writer is a homeopath at Dr Kalyan Banerjee’s Clinic and has led authored research for Oxford University and Imperial College, UK)

Title: Coronavirus has turned PM into a team player
Article:
Modi has had three meetings with Chief Ministers on the counter strategy and also lockdown exit, trying to emerge as a team leader and a consensus-builder

Has the Coronavirus pandemic altered Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s style of functioning? It certainly looks like it. This is because Modi knows that dealing with the pandemic is not only a test of his leadership but also if he succeeds, it will be his legacy, which will be remembered for long.

Hence, the Prime Minister, who till now was known for being a hard taskmaster and for doing his own thing at the risk of offending the Opposition and the people of the country alike (demonetisation and the abrogation of Article 370 in the erstwhile State of Jammu and Kashmir) has shown his softer side to the citizens of late.

He has donned the mantle of the head of a family, a firm yet caring father who must take some tough decisions to lead his family of 1.3 billion through difficult times.

He has been apologetic for the inconvenience and hardship caused to the people during the nationwide lockdown, even though his has been a delayed response to the pandemic and the shutdown was a “just in time” decision despite Congress leader Rahul Gandhi stressing on the need for it many weeks ago.

He has long-last shown a team spirit in dealing with the Chief Ministers (CMs) of the States, irrespective of whether they are BJP-ruled or not. What is even more surprising is the fact that the Prime Minister (who has often been perceived to be unfriendly to the media, particularly those who criticise the Government) has of late taken to appreciating the media for their role in disseminating information on the Coronavirus and the nation’s initiatives. For the first time perhaps, Modi also sought the support of the media and briefed the top editors and media barons on the measures taken by his Government.

Modi has even been taking the leaders of the Opposition into confidence before and after announcing difficult decisions, which is far-removed from his usual style of functioning. Even his oratory shows a persuasive tone.

From January onwards, ever since it became apparent that India was not to be spared the scourge of COVID-19, the Prime Minister has held several rounds of meetings and discussions with various stakeholders in order to find ways and means to fight the pandemic. The first thing he did was to work out a strategy. First he eased the people into a one-day curfew to get them used to the concept. When that turned out to be a success by and large, he announced the 21-day lockdown. He imposed it with apologies and addressed the people thrice in a short span to impress upon them the fact that the nation has to make sacrifices to save the lives of people. Then came the tricky issue of continuing the lockdown for another two weeks, as most CMs wanted it and there was also the question of getting the cooperation of the CMs who didn’t. After all, health is a State subject and without their unstinted cooperation, Coronavirus cannot be tackled. Though Modi had advocated cooperative federalism and competitive federalism in the last six years it was not practised in earnest, as mostly all non–BJP ruled States accused the Centre of playing politics. There had not been too many meetings with the CMs in the last six years, too. So taking them all on board was vital. He had three meetings with CMs on the strategy and also lockdown exit, trying to emerge as a team leader and a consensus-builder.

Modi, on his part, praised different States for their handling of the situation and extensive teamwork. To their credit, the CMs, too, understood the nature of the crisis and the need to show their leadership in their States. Now, as they ask for more funds to tackle the virus, it remains to be seen how Central funds will be distributed.

Earlier, Modi never showed much inclination to deal with the Opposition either in Parliament or outside. The Opposition, too, was divided and weak, with the main party the Congress facing a leadership crisis. Despite that, in a rare gesture Modi showed maturity in taking them into confidence and briefed them on the measures taken by the Government and also sought their views for ways to end the lockdown safely.

The Opposition, including the Congress, did rise to the occasion and give support but there was muted criticism on the plight of the migrant labourers the need for financial relief to the affected and so on. Modi even roped in religious leaders in the fight against Coronavirus and asked the CMs to convene a meeting of religious leaders and ask them to convince their followers to follow the Government’s guidelines.

On the global level, Modi revived the SAARC and established his leadership in the region and other members, too, had to come on board, including Pakistan.

Now the crisis is entering a difficult period. The coming months will be a testing time. There is some exit plan but the real problem is livelihood and the sliding economy. The poor need basics like food, clothing and shelter and this is where the Government should deliver in the coming days. Millions of jobs need to be generated. With an expected huge slide in the global and Indian economy, funds need to be injected without any delay. It is not enough just to disburse money to States. Modi must also ensure that they deliver.

For Modi and the CMs, the present crisis is both a challenge and an opportunity. The country has to battle the worst-ever pandemic. Modi has underlined during his virtual meeting with the CMs that the Government’s earlier stand of “jaan hai to jahaan hai (life is everything)” has now changed to “jaan bhi, jahaan bhi (life and everything with it.” This should indeed become the goal.

(The writer is a senior journalist)

Title: The Corona apocalypse
Article:
With nations across the world facing a critical test, India’s vibrant democracy and cultural generosity have created the synergy needed to face the challenges posed by COVID-19

Some contours of the post-Coronavirus world are clearly visible. The nation State has regained legitimacy; the case for free flow of refugees/immigrants across a borderless world has collapsed; and Governments are facing the critical test of whether they can rally their people behind them to overcome the disease. India has performed remarkably well so far, though critics may carp that steps taken in February and March could have been taken earlier. Perhaps, or as Maurice Maeterlinck mused: “It is easy for those who are wise after the event to see what ought to have been done when time has brought full knowledge of what was really taking place” (Wisdom and Destiny).

Doomsday accounts of Cassandras in reputed (sic) Western media and their acolytes in India have proved demonstrably false. India’s vibrant democracy and cultural generosity have created the synergy needed to face the challenges posed by COVID-19. Immediately after the lockdown was announced, civil society across the country rose as one to daily feed millions in every city, without discrimination; virtually every mandir, matham, gurdwara is at work. Five star hotels, dharamsalas and guest houses are providing quality accommodation for overworked medical staff. Even migrant labourers, who were misguided to leave Delhi or panicked and left other cities, have been provided for by citizens along the route.

The Indian Railways imaginatively converted unused bogeys into quarantine facilities. Research labs, companies and young engineers are innovating to make ventilators, splitters for ventilators, fumigation chambers, protective gear for medical staff, smart stethoscopes and sanitiser trunks. Households are making and distributing masks to the needy. In Pakistan, NGOs are denying food and rations to poor Hindus and Christians suffering from Coronavirus, an act that has angered even its Muslim neighbours. Long suffering Balochistan complains of neglect; medical staff lack Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and quarantine facilities are disgraceful. The silence of the hyperactive international media is deafening.

What makes India’s response unique is the Union Cabinet’s decision to reduce salary, allowances and pensions of all Members of Parliament (MPs) by a whopping 30 per cent for one year, with effect from April 1, 2020. The President, Vice President and Governors voluntarily took a similar pay cut as social responsibility. The MP Local Area Development Scheme (MPLADS) has been suspended for two years (2020-21 and 2021-22); all money saved will go to the Consolidated Fund of India. This scale of personal sacrifice is unmatched in the world so far; even children have been inspired to give their savings (for bicycle, birthday) to feed the needy.

Most noteworthy is the speed with which India evacuated its stranded citizens, first from Wuhan (epicenter of the outbreak) and then from other cities: Milan and Rome; Tehran; Manila and Singapore. Of the 890 people evacuated from COVID-19-affected countries, 48 hailed from the Maldives, Myanmar, Bangladesh, China, the US, Israel, Madagascar, Sri Lanka, Nepal, South Africa and Peru. They were evacuated at the request of their Governments.

Special efforts were made to rescue 124 people quarantined on board the Diamond Princess, the cruise ship off the Japanese port of Yokohama, which included five nationals from Sri Lanka, Nepal, South Africa and Peru. India did offer to rescue Pakistani students from Wuhan but Islamabad rebuffed; seven Maldivians were evacuated.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi held a video conference with leaders of the South Asian nations and launched a fund, with an initial contribution of $10 million, to check the spread of the pandemic in the region. India also responded to requests for emergency medical equipment from Bhutan and the Maldives. The country also participated in the G-20 video conference to discuss containment strategies and the economic impact of the outbreak, especially unemployment.

Our country has already taken the lead in the struggle to develop a vaccine and on April 11, the Department of Science and Technology agreed to fund Seagull BioSolutions Pvt Ltd to develop Active Virosome Vaccine and Immunodiagnostic kits for COVID-19. As the largest manufacturer of hydroxychloroquine (HCQ), currently considered a life-saving drug for fighting Coronavirus, India is supplying it to 30 countries, including the US, and ramping up production for future needs. However, the active pharmaceutical ingredient (API) used to manufacture HCQ comes from China, which continued supplies throughout the crisis but in the coming days, we will have to revisit our domestic manufacturing strategy.

The anti-tuberculosis BCG vaccine is emerging as another potential cure. India’s low death rate is said to be due to its universal immunisation schedule that includes BCG and a fair amount of population immunity to malaria. An ongoing research at the New York Institute of Technology shows that countries that discontinued the BCG vaccine (the US, Italy, Germany, Spain, France, Iran and the UK) have proved very vulnerable to COVID-19.

Comparisons are undesirable at this apocalyptic moment in human history but given the uncalled for attacks on India from some responsible quarters, some points are in order. India saw its first case of Coronavirus in the last week of January, around the same time as Europe and the US. After initially claiming the disease would go away on its own, US President Donald Trump said on March 30 that administration estimates show that COVID-19 could kill 100,000 to 200,000 people in America and such a toll would indicate that his administration has “done a very good job.” Imagine an Indian leader saying such a death toll is acceptable and surviving. At the time of writing, the world had 1,853,327 cases and 114,250 deaths; India had 9,152 cases and 308 mortalities.

The pandemic has inflicted deep pain, disrupting incomes of those dependent on daily wages, creating havoc among small businesses and manufacturing units and triggering mass unemployment. Sadly, India is looking at an extension of the three-week lockdown imposed on March 25 because thousands gathered at the Tablighi Jamaat Markaz in Nizamuddin, Delhi, including 280 from Malaysia, Indonesia, Saudi Arabia and Kyrgyzstan, to attend a meeting on March 13, defied prohibitory orders.

Many left and spread the disease to other States and countries. Police escorted some to the airport after the March 22 janata curfew but they returned surreptitiously; the authorities were called only on March 30 after one person died. Thereafter, the behaviour of many in hospital has been unmentionable. Yet, Indian medical staff have served them with exemplary dedication and moral fortitude; all talk of the “sectoral targetting of a particular community” is invidious and deserves outright condemnation.

(The author is a senior journalist. Views expressed are personal.)

Title: The education mess
Article:
It is at a time like this that one wishes India had taken full advantage of its educational satellite

No school student in Wuhan missed classes as they were conducted for 76 days online. So, it is not surprising that in the times of COVID-19, India, too, has refused to let education become a casualty of the virus. Though we did flounder in the initial days, once it became apparent that we would have to go into extended lockdowns and the school/college year could be truncated, we got our act together. Hence, most schools, top universities and premier institutes of excellence like IITs and IIMs are conducting online classes via Zoom, Microsoft Teams and so on. Not to be left behind, even the Delhi Government is holding online classes for its students as is Haryana. Not just this, all schools have even created parents’ WhatsApp groups to keep them informed about the day-to-day schedule. Homework/projects are being given and so are notes. But obviously courses which need extensive practical knowledge will suffer. As far as possible, India is taking advantage of technology to keep the academic sessions on track and doing whatever it can to ensure that a school year is not wasted. That’s why in most schools, exams for students from Nursery to class VIII have been nixed and children are being promoted to higher classes automatically. Also, the summer vacation is being brought forward so that there can be early resumption of an academic session. However, education in rural India is certainly suffering as schools here don’t have access to PCs/tablets or internet connectivity. Even if students are promoted to the next class sans examinations, they would have largely lost out on the learning process, which might make it difficult for them to cope with next year’s syllabus. It is at a time like this that one wishes that India had taken full advantage of its Educational Satellite (EduSat). Launched in 2004, it had a life span of seven years but it died out in 2010 and we could not use even 10 per cent of its capacity. Similarly, the Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) platform of the Government, known as SWAYAM, and a bouquet of direct to home (DTH) educational channels, all of which cover content from pre-school to doctoral studies, are not able to fill the gap they were expected to in the present crisis. Although a large number of secondary students are watching Channel 27 — Panini — and senior secondary students are watching Channel 28 — Sharda of the Swayam Prabha DTH channels — the viewership is minuscule in comparison to its potential.

If the current crisis has taught us anything, it is the need to incorporate edu-tech within the mainstream education system. If we had done it earlier, we would have been far ahead right now. However, what is really worrying in the present scenario is what is going to happen to students in the 12th grade, who have to join college/universities and those passing out from higher institutions who either want to study further or have to join the workforce. Till now, there is no clarity on when pending/unfinished exams will be over. The tail-end Board exams became a casualty to the Coronavirus and were postponed till the end of April, leaving parents and students alike on tenterhooks. Even if they are conducted late May, assessment of test papers and compilation of results will take a longer time. Unless that is sped up, there is no way a clearer picture can emerge before July/end August. What of entrance tests for further studies? While a few colleges/universities like GGSIPU, JNU and so on have opened their registration, there is no guessing the date of tests. While some institutions, like Christ University, have given the dates for their entrance tests, others are still to draw up a schedule. Clearly, those at the cusp of career-setting exams and interviews are under a huge shadow. Besides, they will be expected to cram about a two to three-month academic course in far lesser time. As it is, job placements have been badly affected with packages being revised or offers withdrawn by most global institutions, which are under increasing pressure of protectionist Governments to use home-grown human resource. The best brains will get hired regardless, the competitive stress will be higher on young minds and the average performers will be disoriented by this choke on the system. May be every student should develop an extra skill set or vocation to tide over these tough times.

Title: Distracted from real thing
Article:
China bank’s stake in HDFC shouldn’t set alarm bells ringing. The Govt must be wary of the Chinese industry

Let us be honest, the collapse in the value of several top-notch companies over the past two months has meant that there are some very good value blue chip stocks available in the market. So, one should see the People’s Bank of China (PBoC)’s acquisition of one per cent stake in the country’s largest private home loan lender, HDFC, as a savvy move. In fact, the PBoC only acquired 0.2 per cent of HDFC this time round, to add to the 0.8 per cent it already held. PBoC, which manages the People’s Republic of China’s sovereign wealth fund, must have felt that the 40 per cent reduction in HDFC’s share price represented good value, just like ordinary punters, who are doubling down on blue chips right now. Shouldn’t India be worried about Chinese investments in Indian companies? Yes it should be but not in this particular case. Because China’s sovereign wealth fund isn’t the single-largest holder of financial assets to own a stake in HDFC. That would be Singapore with 3.3 per cent. In fact, the Abu Dhabi Government and the Norwegian Central bank hold larger stakes in HDFC than China. So China’s extra investment should actually be seen as a vote of confidence in Deepak Parekh, the promoter of HDFC, and in the Indian economy, once we emerge from the Coronavirus episode.

That said, there are some worrying trends about China that Indian policymakers should be wary of. The first is that there is a genuine fear among Indian manufacturers, large and small, that Chinese companies will use their head-start in opening from the lockdown to dump products on them. The Indian economy, particularly small and medium scale manufacturing, may take time, perhaps, till the end of the monsoon, to get back to normalcy. And while countervailing duties are anti-consumer, the Government should look long and hard at imposing such duties if for nothing else to protect manufacturing in the country. Then there is the other issue. Chinese firms have an overweight investment presence in several areas that are strategically important, such as in the financial services space with Jack Ma’s Alibaba Group being the largest shareholder in PayTM. Similarly, in educational technology and several other start-ups, India has allowed wanton investment by China. While Chinese money will bail out the world to a great extent after this incident, India is no exception. We should welcome those investments like the recent one in HDFC. But we have to protect industries and sectors, which are strategically important for India, from undue Chinese influence. This requires strategic thinking as well as an understanding of China, which is buying influence across the world. As the saying goes, there’s no free lunch.

Title: Bhoomi pujan for Ram temple may be held digitally
Article:
|

The much-awaited bhoomi pujan for starting the construction of Ram temple at Ayodhya, slated for April 30, could be held through video conferencing.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh chief Mohan Bhagwat were scheduled to grace the occasion but are now expected to participate in the bhoomi pujan digitally.

Earlier, it was believed that the date of the bhoomi pujan could be extended due to lockdown but now the Ram Janmabhoomi Teerth Kshetra trust is mulling to organise a small function on April 30 so that the construction of temple could start once the lock- down is lifted.

Trust general secretary Champat Rai said in Ayodhya on Monday that they were considering several options and holding the function through video conferencing was one of them.

“We can go for a small function through video conferencing and when the situation normalises, a grand function can be held in which the prime minister and other prominent persons could be invited. However the blueprint will be finalised in the coming days,” he said.

Champat Rai further said that sadhus of Ayodhya wanted the bhoomi pujan on April 30. “This is an auspicious day as per Hindu calendar as Baishakh Shukl saptami falls on this day and the saints are eager to do bhoomi pujan on that day,” Rai said.

Earlier on March 25, idols of Ram Lalla and other deities were shifted to a new makeshift temple in Ayodhya in the presence of Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath.

On November 9 last year, the Supreme Court had delivered a historic judgement, giving the entire Ram Janmabhoomi land to Hindus for the construction of a Ram temple and had asked the government to provide five acres of land to Muslims for construction of a mosque at an alternative place in Ayodhya.

The UP government has already provided the required land to Muslims on the border of Ayodhya district and it has been accepted by UP Sunni Central Waqf Board.

Title: No new COVID-19 case in last 5 days in U’khand
Article:
No new patient of the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) was reported for fifth consecutive day in Uttarakhand on Monday. The state has so far reported 35 cases of the pandemic which has affected more than 9000 people in different parts of the country. Out of these 35 patients, seven patients have recovered completely and have been discharged from the hospitals.

Addressing media persons on Monday, the additional secretary, medical health and family welfare department, Yugal Kishore Pant said, “We are lucky that no new case of the disease surfaced in the state in last five days but it does not mean that the virus is not in the area. We have to remain vigilant and continue with the practice of social distancing and washing of the hands with soap at regular intervals till we are free from the virus,’’ he said.

Pant said that the 108 emergency ambulance service has been asked to pick up and drop the patients of suffering from critical diseases. He said that the State Government is continuously improving the health system in the State. “In the 16 dedicated COVID treatment centres in the state we have 110 ICU beds for COVID-19 patients. We are in process of adding 325 more ICU beds in these centres,’’ he said.

Pant informed that reports of 149 suspected patients were received by the department on Monday and all of them were found negative for the disease. He said that reports of 298 samples are still awaited. The authorities have so far taken swab samples of 1998 suspected patients for COVID-19 test. On Monday samples of 131 suspected patients was taken and sent to the lab for test. A total of 1814 people are under institutional quarantine while 447 suspected patients in hospital isolation. The authorities have sent 53862 people are in home quarantine in different parts of the state.

The Additional Chief Executive Officer (ACEO) of Uttarakhand Disaster Management Authority (USDMA), Riddhim Aggarwal said that the state government is making its preparation for worst has so far identified facilities to keep 20000 people in institutional quarantine. She said guest houses of GMVN, KMVN, sainik kalyan, ITBP and other departments would be used as institutional quarantine centres when needed. A nodal officer in every district has been appointed to check the preparedness of these centres.

She said that the SDRF and NDRF personnel providing training to those who are in frontline of battle against COVID-19 or are exposed to the disease. Aggarwal informed that the administration has identified and sealed 11 areas in the state to contain the spread of the virus.

Title: No new cases in 100 hrs but vital to maintain alertness: CM
Article:
There have been no new cases of COVID-19 in Uttarakhand during the past about 100 hours while seven patients have recovered and returned home. The lab report of two-three patients is likely to be negative in the coming few days.

However, future uncertainties cannot be rejected because ymptoms of COVID-19 are either not being seen or being seen after many days in some cases.

Considering this, it is vital to maintain a high level of alertness, said the Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat.

Interacting with the media at the secretariat after discharging various official tasks on Monday the CM exhorted the people to cover their faces in any way.

Using a mask and maintaining social distancing can provide about 80 per cent safety from the virus.

Referring to the incident at Vanbhulpura in Haldwani when a large crowd had created disturbance when a Government team went to administer a health check to a Maulvi in a mosque on Sunday, the CM said that considering the situation he had ordered imposition of curfew in the area. Stressing that the State government will take strict measures for containment of COVID-19, he appealed religious leaders, intelligentsia and social workers to assist the state government in raising public awareness. At a time when COVID-19 pandemic is afflicting the world, long term alertness is required to tackle this problem, he said.

Regarding the lockdown, Rawat said that the Central government had formed a committee for exit plan for the lockdown.

A uniform policy will have to be implemented in the nation to tackle this crisis.

The State government is awaiting the Centre’s exit plan and will take a decision according to it.

The lockdown will have to be eased gradually and Uttarakhand government has also given its suggestions to the Government of India regarding this. In general, the opinion of all the states is same regarding the lockdown, added the CM

Title: Decision on reopening Char Dham, other shrines after Central directions: Maharaj
Article:
The State’s Tourism and Culture Minister Satpal Maharaj said that a decision on reopening the Char Dham and other shrines will be taken on the basis of directions from the Central Government. He said this while chairing a video conference with officials concerned regarding the scheduled reopening of the shrines.

As per religious beliefs and ancient traditions, the Char Dham shrines- Yamunotri, Gangotri, Kedarnath and Badrinath along with other important shrines including Tungnath and Bhavishya Badri are closed during the winters and reopened during the summer.

However, due to the nation-wide lockdown to contain the spread of COVID-19, the authorities are in a dilemma regarding the reopening of these important shrines. The reopening of the Char Dham and other important shrines is slated to begin later this month. Maharaj held a video conference with officials concerned to review the possibility of reopening these shrines.

He said that presently there are no COVID-19 positive cases or contagion in Uttarkashi, Chamoli and Rudraprayag districts- where the Char Dham shrines are located. “After reviewing the possibility of reopening the Char Dham shrines, Tungnath and Bhavishya Badri, we are sending this in writing to the Central Government.

Whether these shrines can be reopened or not and if opened will only the necessary priests be allowed or nobody will be allowed to enter the shrines- all this will depend on the Centre’s decision and a decision will taken as per the Centre’s directions.

A decision on opening the Dharmshalas on the Yatra route will be taken after the lockdown is lifted.

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic and lockdown, what is being considered presently is how to initiate ritual worship while maintaining social distancing without devotees after opening these shrines. The media will be informed about the decision taken in this regard,” said the Minister.

Title: Many competitive exams including NEET postponed
Article:
With the outbreak of pandemic COVID-19, many competitive examinations have been postponed. Among which National Eligibility Entrance Test (NEET) is also postponed. With the lockdown, National Testing Agency (NTA) has given an opportunity to the students to make changes in their online applications.

It is to be noted that the candidates can change their choice of city centres. The notice read, “In continuation of PUBLIC NOTICE dated 01.04.2020 issued by the National Testing Agency regarding correction facility in the Particulars of Online Application Form for NEET(UG)-2020,

it is further notified that in view of the hardships faced by the aspirants of NEET(UG) -2020 due to COVID-19 epidemic, the NTA has further expanded the scope of making corrections in the Application Form. The scope now also includes changes in the choice of cities for centre opted by the candidates for NEET (UG)- 2020.”

It further reads, “The NTA will make efforts to allow the city of examination to the candidates in order of choices now opted by them in their application form. However, due to administrative reasons, a different city may be allotted and the decision of the NTA regarding allotment of Centre shall be final.”

The dates of issuance of admit cards of NEET were also extended till April 15, due to lockdown.

The largest entrance examination for UG medical courses, National Eligibility cum Entrance Test (NEET) is the gateway for admissions to medical (MBBS), dental (BDS), and AYUSH courses in country. The test will be conducted as per regulations of the Indian Medical Council Act-1956 and Dentists Act-1948, and as amended from time to time.

Title: Pritam pitches for loan waiver of farmers
Article:
Reminding the BJP of the promise of loan waiver for farmers made by it ahead of assembly elections of 2017, the Pradesh Congress Committee (PCC) president, Pritam Singh has said that it is high time when the BJP Government of Uttarakhand should fulfil this promise. Talking to media persons at the state headquarters of the Congress party on Monday, Singh said that the lock-down has adversely affected the farmers and in such a scenario, the Government should waive off their loans. “It is very important to keep the morale of the farmers’ high and their economic condition stable as they are bread providers of the country. The State Government should increase the minimum support price of the food-grains and clear pending dues of the sugarcane farmers,’’ he said. Singh added that the crop of wheat is ready in the fields for harvesting so the Government should start procurement centres.

The PCC president said that complaints of Asha workers and sanitation workers non availability of face masks, sanitizers and other equipment are unfortunate. He said that all those who are in frontline in the fight against novel Coronavirus should be provided good quality masks, sanitizers, Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) kits and gloves in sufficient numbers. All these corona warriors should be adequately insured.

Singh said that under the prevailing circumstances it is highly unlikely that the world famous Char Dham Yatra would commence on scheduled dates. He said that the shopkeepers, those associated with hotel industry and others would be hit hard by the adverse effect of COVID-19 on Yatra this year. Singh said that the economy would get the battering and it is for the government to make plans so that it comes back on track.

The PCC president also demanded that more ration per unit should be provided to the poor. He said that the ration provided per card is not sufficient. “The daily wage earners and those doing small jobs and business are the hardest hit by the lock-down. Under the prevailing circumstances arrangement for more food grain should be made in the ration shops so that such families tide over the situation,’’ he said.

The PCC president said that all the followers of the Tablighi Jamat who had attended the congregations in Delhi and other areas should come forward and help in fight against the COVID-19. He said that getting tested is the only way of preventing the spread of infection.

On extension of lock-down enforced in the state to break the infection cycle of the disease, Pritam Singh said that he is in favour of extension and the state government too has recommended the same to the union government. He however added that the state government should not remain dependent on the union government and make its own decisions based on the situation.

Title: Relief camp inmates resume eating after assurance
Article:
Some of the people from other states kept in two of the five relief camps in Laksar refused to eat food, demanding that they be sent back to their homes. After spending 14 days in the relief camp, some of the people from other States including Punjab, Haryana, Rajasthan and Uttar Pradesh demanded that they be sent to their homes. Officials reached the camps and informed them that a decision regarding this could be taken only on the directions of the Central Government. After receiving assurance from officials, they resumed eating food.

About 150 persons from other states stranded here due to the lockdown have been housed in five relief camps in Laksar area of Haridwar.

The Laksar SDM Puran Singh Rana informed that in two of the five relief camps, some of the people started demanded that they be sent back home by the authorities.

Some of them refused to eat food in support of their demand. However, on being informed about the situation and assured of necessary action based on government directions, they resumed eating. The SDM added that proper arrangements have been made for food and other necessary facilities in these relief camps.

Title: After 7 new cases, Ujjain also becoming corona hotspot
Article:
After emergence of seven cases on Monday panic gripped in the region and along with Indore and Bhopal, Ujjain is also becoming a hotspot of Corona in Madhya Pradesh as the number of corona infected patients in Ujjain is increasing steadily.

With this, the number of corona patients in Ujjain has increased to 25 creating restlessness in the administration and health department.

The number of patients have continued to increase for the past two days. Ujjain stands after Indore and Bhopal in the number of cases reported in the state. On Monday the suspected patients who were tested positive for corona Shabbir father Shahid(75) resident of Begum Bagh, Sajid father Shakir Hussain(32) resident Nagauri Mohalla,

Mohammad Hussain father Ibrahim(65) resident KD Gate, Abid Ali father Najabuddin(56) resident Kamri Marg, Shabida Bi husband Mohammad Hussain(60) resident KD Gate, Manisha husband Jayant(60) Kamri Marg and Jasina B husband Riaz Ahmed(60) Amarpura Topkhana. The number of deaths is 5 while 4 corona infected have recovered and discharged. The corona report of 7 patients who came positive were surveyed door to door by administration and samples were collected for examination if corona-like symptoms were found.

After receiving these seven new patients from Corona, administration has started preparations to declare the areas of Begambagh, Nagauri Mohalla, Kamari Marg, Amarpura Topkhana as the Containment Area where new corona patients have been found.

On Sunday reports of 71 patients was received in which 2 were tested positive. A 65-year-old woman and a 7-year-old boy.

Title: CM for rabi procurement in MP except Indore, Ujjain
Article:
Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan has said that the Rabi procurement on support price will be started in all districts except Indore, Ujjain and Bhopal from coming April 15 in the State.

During this time, procurement should be ensured by following social distancing and all other protective measures in the mandis. Chouhan said that this time farmers are being given facility to sell their foodgrain directly to the traders even outside the mandis.

The Chief Minister was reviewing the preparations for Rabi procurement work in the state along with senior officials in Mantralaya. Chief Secretary Iqbal Singh Bains, Secretary Public Relations P Narhari and all concerned officers were present in the meeting. The Chief Minister instructed that farmers should be informed through SMS about the date and in which shift they have to come to the support price centers to sell their crops.

It should be ensured that farmers come and sell the crop on the same day and in the shift. Such arrangements should be made that about 10 to 12 farmers are called daily for procurement.

It was informed that due to the present circumstances of Corona, this time the farmers are being given the facility to sell their grain directly to the traders on support price through ‘Sauda Patrak’. This system lasted till 2009 in the state, after which it was discontinued. In addition, farmers will also be able to sell their produce at ITC procurement centers. It was informed at the meeting that for the purchase of gram, lentil and mustard at support price, procurement centres are being built outside the mandis this year as well.

The number of these centers is 790, which will be sufficient. These grains are likely to be purchased at a support price of about 8 lakh MT.

Chouhan directed that all arrangements for gunny bags, weighing, loading, transportation of food grains, storage etc. at procurement centers should be excellent to purchase grain at support price from farmers. Special vigilance needs to be taken due to Corona crisis.

Title: Ambedkar university online seminar today
Article:
BR Ambedkar University of Social Sciences (BRAUSS) is organising an online seminar on Tuesday. The online seminar is organised on the occasion of 129th birth anniversary of BR Ambedkar.

The online seminar will be held on the theme Social Assimilation, Gender Equality and Development of Weaker Sections. The session will be conducted by Vice Chancellor Prof Asha Shukla is Chairperson and Prof DK Verma.

The registration for the online session can be done through sending an application on dkvbrauss@gmail.com or on WhatsApp number 99260l5814.

The participants can prepare on the themes like Ambedkar‘s Vision for Social Assimilation. Women Empowerment and SDGs2030, Social Assimilation Conceptual Mapping, Approaches and Strategies, Gender Equality Theoretical Frame, Empirical Cases and Policy Interventions, Social Science Response to Marriage, Family and Gender Equality,

Gender Sociology, Status, Role and Social Change towards Equality, Gender Budget Changing Economy Panics, Participation and Prospects, Gender Sensitisation- Identity. Dignity and Empowerment and Thoughts of BR Ambcdkar, Egalitarian Society and Emerging Gender Order.

Accepted online presentations will be published by the University in a special volume commemorating 129th Birth Anniversary of BR Ambedkar, for which full length and updated papers are requested latest by May 15.

Title: Masks to be provided to labourers working under MNREGA: Official
Article:
Home-made masks will be provided to the labourers working under the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Scheme (MNREGA) in the State to protect them from corona virus infection.

These masks are being made by the women self-help groups working under the mission. Additional Chief Secretary Rural Development Manoj Shrivastava has informed that the Ministry of Rural Development of the Government of India has advised all the states to provide hand-made masks to the labourers working under the Mahatma Gandhi NREGA scheme to protect them from COVID-19 infection.

He said that in this connection it has been decided by the Government of Madhya Pradesh to provide home-made masks made by the women self-help groups formed in the National Rural Livelihood Mission under the Rural Development Department to the MNREGA labourers.

He has said that the norms set by the Union Ministry of Health for preparing masks is also being ensured.

He informed that 2 lakh 87 thousand self help groups are working under the Rural Livelihood Mission in the state. The women members of these groups have been advised to prepare masks.

The masks produced by them have been named 'Home-Made Masks'.

In maximum districts of the state, the women members of the groups have already started preparing masks. So far, over 25.42 lakh have already been prepared by 1927 groups. In addition to this, 26,431 liter sanitizer and 3,000 PPE kits have also been prepared. These groups have also produced 52,246 hand wash soaps.

The Additional Chief Secretary, Manoj Shrivastava said that these items made by the women members of self-help groups are being made available to the MGNREGA workers and also to the poor beneficiaries of SC-ST categories of urban and rural areas as well as small farmers.

Title: 27-year-old college youth commits suicide for not getting job
Article:
Depressed over failing to get job a 27-year-old college youth committed suicide by hanging with the ceiling at Ahata Mantasha under Aishbagh police station area on Sunday.

According to police the deceased idenitified as Faizal Khan had been trying to get a job but failed in his attempts and committed suicide in the evening on Sunday at her grandparents’ house.The deceased hailed from Delhi and after graduating from Delhi he came to Bhopal in February this year to stay with his maternal grandparents. On Sunday evening he was found hanging from the ceiling of his room after which he was taken to hospital where he was declared dead. Police have not found any suicide note. The family members told that he took the extreme step after failing to get a job and used to remain depressed over his unemployment. The mobile phone of the youth has been seized while the parents have been informed. Further investigation has been stared after registering a case by police.

Meanwhile, a 15-year-old boy got electrocuted while cleaning water cooler at his village Birpur under Eitkhedi police station area on Sunday.

Title: Alternative medicine teams join battle against corona
Article:
The teams of alternative systems of medicine have joined the battle of defeating the corona virus. They are playing important role in the identified areas of the districts.

It is worth noticing here that following the instructions of Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chauhan, Ayurvedic doctors are distributing preventive and immunity boosting medicines to the common people. Homoeopathy medicines are also being given in some areas.

The people have showered praise on the team members approaching them. They have appreciated the initiative of providing preventive Ayurvedic medicine.

In Bhopal, Khushi Lal Sharma Government Ayurveda Hospital's Medical Officer along with the subordinate staff are going to the identified areas and advising people to save themselves from the corona virus.

It is noteworthy that the Chief Minister had also given instructions to give AYUSH medicines. Medicines have been distributed to millions of people in many districts.

Mainly people are being given trikatu churna and samsamani vati. It is advisable to have 5 gms of Trikatu Churna, Basil 3 to 5 leaves, one liter of water after boiling it and reduce to half and tske sip.

It is also recommended to take 2 tablets in morning, and two in the evening. These medicines will boost immunity. Khushi Lal Sharma Government Ayurveda Hospital Bhopal is providing relief to the residents in Kolar region. Ayurveda Medical Officer Dr Prabin Raghuvanshi informs that 15 teams of Khushi Lal Sharma Government Ayurveda Hospital Bhopal are distributing Ayurvedic medicines free of cost in identified areas.

Each team consists of seven members, who are going door-to-door explaining them to use the medicines. The Ayurveda and Homoepathy medical teams are giving the message to people to stay alert and healthy.

Residents of the Kolar region greeted them by clapping. The efforts of administration and enthusiastic public support will help control the spread of Corona virus.

Title: 22-year-old girl attacked by two miscreants with sharp-edged weapons
Article:
A 22-year-old girl was attacked by two miscreants with sharp-edged weapons after she opposed teasing and molestation at Kabeetpura under Teelajamalpura police station on Sunday; her brother sustained injury in rescuing her.

According to the police, the victim and her brother were was attacked by miscreants identified as Rizwan and Aman with a sharp-edged weapon in which the victim’s brother sustained injuries in his right hand.

The injured victim was rushed to a nearby hospital where she was provided with treatment. Police in the initial investigation found that one of the accused Rizwan who lives in the same area reached the area and informed that free ration distribution is going on and on hearing the information the victim came out for collecting the ration while she was on her way Rizwan teased and molested her which she opposed and raised alarm which alerted her brother who came to her rescue but before he could rescue Rizwan’s brother Aman came with a sharp edged weapon and attacked them.

In a bid to save himself he sustained injuries in his hand. The victim lodged a complaint with Gautam Nagar police and based on the complaint and after the preliminary investigation,the police have registered a case under sections 294 and 324 of the IPC and have started further investigation. The miscreants are yet to be arrested. Police said that crime record of the accused would be investigated. The house and other places were raided but the accused managed to remain absconding.

Title: Like other employees, drivers too work round clock braving Covid-19
Article:
Like employees of other services like Health, police and BMC, Tourism department's drivers are also working round the clock braving Coronavirus.

To help doctors, nursing staff and sanitation workers with medicines and medical supplies in every division and districts of the State, more than 20 drivers of Madhya Pradesh Tourism Development Corporation have been working for the last 18 days round the clock, said Principal Secretary of Madhya Pradesh Tourism Faiz Ahmed Kidwai.

Kidwai said that these drivers are among the Corona warriors who have maintained the availability of equipment, infection prevention products such as sanitisers, mask PPE kits, personal globes, etc.

The transport wing has worked like a warrior, away from home and family in this hour of crisis and under hard situation working day and night to dispense their duty. The mutual cooperation and coordination between MP Tourism Development Corporation, and MP Public Health Services Corporation Ltd (MPPHSCL), availability and continuity of medicines and other medical related items throughout the state has been maintained.

The fleet of the transport branch of the Tourism Corporation consists 14-15 Toyota Innova , 4-5 Tempo Traveler vehicles which are being used for Medical Equipments and other medical related items as per demand and requirement and number could be increase. If some kind of repair work in these vehicles is required the workshop of the transport branch are also functional.

All drivers have also been provided with masks and sanitisers, as well as proper arrangements for their food has been made.

Title: Covid-19 pandemic is far from over; lessons from history can’t be overlooked
Article:
One has been witnessing a sense of déjà vu in social media among some sections of Indian population and few of the people from Uttarakhand--particularly motivated as no new case has surfaced in last five days in the State- about the possible control of deadly novel coronavirus (COVID-19) disease in the not too distant future.

This euphoric feeling perhaps emanates from the fact that our national casualties in comparison to some of the worst hit countries of the developed western world are relatively marginal. We are indeed in the midst of one of the worst crises that the world has witnessed. History will judge us harshly if we do not learn from the lessons of fighting similar pandemic of the past and superficially venture into arriving at any hasty conclusion on the prevailing crises of COVID-19 pandemic.

Spanish flu in 1918 accounted for approximately 1.8 crore deaths in India and 10 crore from various countries across the globe. India lost about 6 per cent of its population and 1/5th of the total death toll was from India. This Spanish flew had destroyed the Indian economy. The pandemic had spread with unimaginable speed and India under the British rule then was highly unprepared to deal with such a deadly pandemic. The healthcare system had completely broken down. Most of the medical efforts then were busy attending to WW I casualties. The Spanish flu came to India through a ship deployed for world war efforts and which berthed at Mumbai port. The deadly disease spread like a wildfire and the overcrowded city of Mumbai became a fertile ground for spread of this pandemic further across the length and width of the nation. As per some accounts, banks of river Ganga were swollen with dead bodies and even shortage of wood was experienced for cremation of the deceased.
