Vidhan Sabha, Ministers, Deputy Speaker, Members of Legislative Assembly of Himachal Pradesh, Chairmen and Vice Chairmen of various Boards and Corporations and all political appointees for one year, he said.

Title: Private school fees deferred till June-end
Article:
Keeping in view the financial condition of parents during the COVID-19 pandemic, All Odisha Private School Association (AOPSA) has decided to defer payment of school fees of the students.

At a meeting of the AOPSA, it was decided to give an option to parents to deposit school fees of three months from April to and June without fine by the end of June after opening of schools.

As to why the fees were not waived, the AOPSA said that over 5 lakh employees are engaged in around 9,000 private schools in the State. During the lockdown, the schools authorities are under extreme pressure to bear monthly salaries of employees, school rent and other expenses, said AOPSA president Satya Narayan Mishra.

The AOPSA meeting was convened after Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik had urged the private schools to consider reduction or deferment of school fees from April to June.

Title: First Baisakhi in decades without revelry in Punjab
Article:
This was perhaps the first Baisakhi in decades where the usual revelry and rush of devotees in gurdwaras was missing in Punjab on Monday as people in the state largely celebrated the festival indoors amid a curfew imposed to check the spread of coronavirus.

Baisakhi is one of Punjab's biggest festivals and celebrates the foundation of ''Khalsa Panth'' (Sikh order) by the tenth Sikh Guru, Gobind Singh. It also marks the start of harvest season.

The Golden Temple in Amritsar, one of Sikhism's holiest shrines, saw very few devotees turn up to offer prayers. Normally, nearly two lakh devotees visit the shrine on Baisakhi.

The Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee (SGPC), which manages gurdwaras in Punjab, Haryana, Himachal Pradesh and Chandigarh, had deployed teams to discourage people from assembling.

SGPC Chief Secretary Roop Singh said the committee has never stopped anyone from coming to the Golden Temple but one should not violate the government orders. Barricades were put up at all roads leading to the Golden Temple to prevent overcrowding, a police official said. Similar scenes were witnessed at the Takht Kesgarh Sahib in the holy city of Anandpur Sahib, where the Khalsa Panth was founded in 1699.

Managements of several other gurdwaras across Punjab and state capital Chandigarh politely refused to let devotees inside. They appealed to them to offer prayers at homes and listen to ''gurbani'' online.

"In the morning, devotees came to pay obeisance but we requested them to offer prayers at their homes and also asked them to listen to kirtan on our YouTube channel. We have shared a link of the video of kirtan with devotees on our WhatsApp group," said an official of Gurdwara Sri Guru Tegh Bahadur Sahib in Chandigarh.

He said normally, 60,000 to 70,000 devotees visit the shrine on Baisakhi every year. "It is for the first time that we could not enter the gurdwara," a disappointed devotee said. The management of a gurdwara in Ludhiana said it will reach out to those on the front-line of the fight against coronavirus on the occasion of Baisakhi. "We will distribute langar among front-line workers, including policemen and medical staff," a gurdwara official said. Meanwhile, Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh thanked the people of the state for responding to his appeal for ''Ardas'' (prayer) at 11 am from their homes, and celebrating the auspicious festival of Baisakhi indoors in the larger interest of all. The chief minister, who led the Baisakhi prayers with an Ardas at his home, hoped that the collective prayers of the people would keep Punjab safe and ensure its victory over the deadly coronavirus.

Earlier, the Akal Takht (the highest temporal seat of Sikhs) had asked members of the Sikh community to offer prayers at home on Baisakhi and directed Sikh organisations not to organise religious gatherings on the festival in the view of the Covid-19 outbreak.

Title: Pb bans installation of disinfection tunnels
Article:
Punjab Government on Monday banned the installation and use of disinfection tunnels. The State Health and Family Welfare Director, in a letter to all the Deputy Commissioners and Civil Surgeons, has recommended that disinfection tunnels should not be installed and used.

In fact, some districts have set up hypochlorite spray tunnels for disinfection of people.

The cited the advisory issued by the World Health Organization (WHO) stating that spraying disinfectants like alcohol or chlorine all over the body does not kill the virus rather can be harmful for clothes or mucous membranes.

“Hypochlorite solution is recommended for disinfection of surfaces and instruments. Moreover disinfection tunnels will create a false sense of security and people may be diverted from hand wash to disinfection tunnel,” read the letter.

Title: 400 foreigners stranded in Punjab leave for home
Article:
From alien to homeland, the journey began for about 400 foreign nationals on Monday. Left high and dry in Punjab after the curfew was clamped across the State amidst corona scare on March 23, the foreign nationals, including students, are now safely heading back to their homes.

A week after over 303 US and Canadian nationals evacuated from Punjab, a special chartered flight flew back 271 Britons on Monday besides a special flight from Bhutan evacuating as many as 134 Bhutanese students of which maximum were stranded at a hostel of LPU, Phagwara, where a positive case was reported.

The Jammu&Kashmir Administration has also agreed to take back 1,400 stranded Kashmiri migrants, who had been put up in the relief camps at Pathankot. Pathankot District Administration is now awaiting the final go ahead from Kathua Deputy Commissioner to send them back at Lakhanpur barrier.

“This will also open the way for the return of Kashmiri students stranded in Amritsar, who have already completed their quarantine period,” said the Special Chief Secretary Karan Bir Singh Sidhu, who is also handling Punjab Disaster Management (Covid-19). He added that Jammu and Kashmir being a UT now, “they are getting all their permissions from the Union Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA)”. A special plane from Bhutan flew back as many as 134 Bhutanese students studying in various educational institutions in Punjab, after thoroughly examining them by a team of the Health Department.

“134 Bhutanese students, who had been stranded in the hostels of Lovely Professional University, Phagwara-Jalandhar, were allowed them to leave for Bhutan through a special flight arranged by Bhutanese Government,” said the Special Chief Secretary Karan Bir Singh Sidhu.

Of the total, 122 students are studying at Lovely Professional University. Sidhu said that these students were stranded in the university hostels ever since the start of lockdown in the State.

Meanwhile, a special international non-scheduled rescue flight by the British Airways took off from Amritsar International Airport on Monday afternoon carrying 271 British Nationals.

“British High Commission’s special chartered flight is taking-off from Amritsar International Airport today at 2:30 pm, carrying 271 passengers. They are all British Nationals,” said Sidhu.

Title: 5 more suspects test +ve for Covid-19 in State
Article:
At least five fresh cases of coronavirus, including three from Capital city, were reported in Jharkhand on Monday, taking the total count of active Covid-19 cases in the State to 24, health officials said. With 11 cases in Ranchi, the State capital continues to be the worst-affected district in Jharkhand, they added.

"Samples of five suspects tested positive on Monday. Three of them are from Ranchi, and one each from Bokaro and Giridih," said Health Secretary Nitin Madan Kulkarni. "All the three new cases in Ranchi are from Hindpiri," he added.

Two Bokaro residents tested positive for COVID-19 on Sunday late evening, taking the count of coronavirus cases in the district to eight. On Monday, the count of cases in the district increased to nine. The duo, which tested positive on Sunday, visited Varanasi in March and may have contracted the virus from the city, said Bokaro Sub Divisional Magistrate Prem Ranjan. The two are related to a 75-year-old man who died of COVID-19 infection earlier this week, sources said.

Out of the 24 cases reported in the State so far, two patients –one each from Ranchi and Bokaro– have died, officials said. Out of the 22 active cases in State, 10 are from Ranchi, eight from Bokaro, two from Hazaribag and one each from Koderma and Giridih.

While the cases have been on the rise, the Government has managed to restrict all the cases to affected localities only. In Bokaro, five cases have been reported from Telo and three from Saram. Meanwhile, in Ranchi, all the active cases have been reported from Hindpiri. "We do not have isolated cases from other areas of the two districts, and that is quite a relief, given the circumstances," said a health official.

According to a report released by National Health Mission (NHM), by Monday the Government collected samples of 2523 Coronavirus suspects, and 1963 of them have tested negative. The lab test of the samples collected from 541 suspects is under process, it added.

Also, the number of people in home quarantine has reduced from 1.3 lakh to 1.07 lakh, indicating that around 24,000 people in home quarantine have shown no symptoms of the viral infection, the NHM report said. Nearly 15,000 people have been kept in quarantine centres across the State, it added.

Coronavirus cases in Jharkhand have shown an upward trajectory in April despite entering the State as late as March 31. All the 24 cases here, and the two deaths, were reported in less than a fortnight – a cause for concern for the Government here, say officials. None of the patients here have been cured so far.

Title: Agri, marine fisheries, food processing exempted
Article:
Even as Odisha is battling the coronavirus crisis and going to remain under the second phase of lockdown till April 30, the State Government made a few exemptions on Monday.

Addressing a Press meet, Special Relief Commissioner Pradeep Jena said transportation of seeds, movement of tractor would be allowed during the second phase of lockdown. Vegetables would be procured directly from farmer producer organisations. All cold storages and godowns would be kept open.

Jena said that in view of the harvesting of Rabi crop and the upcoming Kharif season, the Government has decided to exempt farming and the subsequent irrigation of the farmlands in the second phase of lockdown. Movement of the equipments and vehicles like tractors would be allowed during this period. All shops relating to manure, sale and repair of agricultural equipments would also remain open.

“All cooperative banks and LAMPSCS will remain open for the farmers for availability of loans for the Kharif season. The programmes under MGNREGA, PMAY, Biju Pucca Ghar and Swachh Bharat will continue too,” he said.

Fisheries and Animal Husbandry-related activities, food processing and packing units, veterinary services, marine fisheries and hatchery activities, chemical testing, fertiliser testing and seed testing laboratories, plantation and nursery activities have been exempted from the lockdown rules, he added.

In a relief for truckers and transporters, the roadside dhabas and restaurants would be allowed to open but only for takeaway and home-delivery purposes. No food can be consumed there

Jena said home delivery of all kinds of products and courier services by platforms like Amazon, Flipkart, Blue Dart, DTDC and BigBasket would also resume in the remaining lockdown period..

The exemptions made earlier by both the Central and State Governments during the lockdown would remain intact. Besides, the Government would also issue a special set of lockdown norms which would be implemented in the capital city Bhubaneswar during the second phase of lockdown, said Jena.

Title: ‘Abused’ home quarantined man kills self
Article:
A 32-year-old man under home quarantine for coronavirus allegedly committed suicide by hanging in Jajpur district on Sunday night.

Before his death, Suresh Sahoo of Deoda village had posted a video on the social media stating that some villagers abused and assaulted him and refused to pay him money which they had borrowed from him.

Sahoo had been home-quarantined after he returned from Chennai on March 18 to check spread of COVID-19. He was working in a hotel in Chennai.

Sahoo hanged himself from the ceiling fan in his house at Deoda under the Dharmasala police station. Police seized his body and sent it to the District Headquarters.

“After examining Suresh Sahoo’s video, we have detained ten villagers, whom the deceased named in the video,” said Dharmasala police station IIC Saroj Sahoo.

Title: Soaring temperatures double the trouble
Article:
Already finding it tough to fight against the coronavirus, the State is now faced with another challenge, heat wave.

On Monday, 12 stations of the State recorded temperature above 40 degree Celsius. Capital Bhubaneswar and Titilagarh turned the hottest places with temperature of 41.5 degree each. They were followed by Balangir at 41.2 degree and Baripada at 41 degree.

Chandbali and Angul were at 40.7 degree each, Talcher 40.5, Boudh 40.5, Malkangiri 40.2, Nayagarh and Paralakhemundi 40 degree each. Cuttack recorded maximum temperature of 40.1 degree.

Though nobody is sure whether the rise in temperature would help contain the COVID-19 spread, the Odisha State Disaster Management Authority (OSDMA) feels the situation may compound the challenges in controlling the coronavirus.

OSDMA Managing Director PK Jena had earlier written to the district Collectors urging them to put standard operating procedures (SOPs) in place for implementing the heat action plan.

Officials feel the heat wave may not cause much harm as most of the people remain indoors. However, the Government is worried for the safety of the people engaged in the battle against the corona pandemic.

Title: Ranchi looks for its own ‘Hart Island' for Covid-19 victims
Article:
As coronavirus cases witness an unprecedented surge in Jharkhand, Ranchi has started looking for its own Hart Island – a historical plot of land where New York City has buried thousands of pandemic victims, right from the days of Spanish Flu to COVID-19.

While the body of Ranchi's first COVID-19 victim was denied place in Ratu Road Kabaristan over fear of transmission among locals on Sunday, the district administration on Monday was still in the process of finalising an area where victims of the lethal virus could be cremated sans public uproar.

"We have identified four places where such bodies can be buried. However, the final call is yet to be taken," said Ranchi Sub Divisional Officer Lokesh Mishra. "These areas are away from residential localities," he added without disclosing the spots.

The 60-year-old Hindpiri man, who died on Sunday while undergoing treatment at the Isolation Ward of Rajendra Institute of Medical Sciences (RIMS), was buried at a graveyard in Hindpiri after locals at Ratu Road raised a ruckus over the administration's decision of burying his body at Ratu Road Kabaristan.

Social distancing went for a toss on Sunday after hundreds of locals took to the streets in protest against the burial of the Coronavirus victim at Ratu Road Kabaristan. Police had to intervene to pacify the infuriated crowd, and eventually, there was calm in the neighbourhood only after the body was taken away.

"We did not expect such backlash from people. The decision of finding an isolated place for burying COVID-19 victims was taken in the wake of the public uproar," said a police official who was deployed near the Ratu Road Kabaristan on Sunday.

The Bombay High Court recently ruled that bodies of the victims of COVID-19 can be buried in the city, provided the burial ground is away from residential areas. The court quashed a Bombay Municipal Corporation's circular that said that the bodies of COVID-19 victims have to be buried outside the city.

Although Ranchi has witnessed only one COVID-19 death so far, finding a safe burial ground for future casualties seems to be a daunting task given the rapidly expanding nature of the city, sources said. "We have to look for baron lands, preferably in places that are unlikely to see constructions in the near future," said an official in the district administration, requesting anonymity.

Ranchi has reported the highest number of COVID-19 cases in Jharkhand so far. By now, 11 residents of the State capital –all from Hindpiri– have tested positive.

Title: Cabinet nod to GoM for Covid-19 fight
Article:
The Jharkhand Cabinet on Monday constituted a Group of Ministers (GoM) that will look in various problems and their remedial measures arising out due of Covid19.

The group of ministers includes finance and planning minister Rameshwar Oroan, Health minister Banna Gupta and State Labour resources minister Satyanand Bhokta. The group of ministers will be eyes and ears of government to tackle the coronavirus pandemic.

The State Cabinet at its meeting held at Project Bhavan Secretariat and being attended by Chief Minister Hemant Soren also initiated various steps such as welfare schemes in tackling Covid 19 pandemic.

In a big relief and financial assistance to labourers, the Cabinet gave its nod to a decision under which lawmakers can utilize Rs 25 lakh in providing financial assistance to labourers. Cabinet Coordination department principal secretary Ajay Kumar Singh said, “As per Cabinet decision an MLA can recommend financial help of Rs 1000 to poor families and Rs 2000 to those who are stuck in other parts of country due to lockdown.

The MLA can recommend the name of the beneficiary along with the labourer’s account number to DDC and though DBT the money will be credited in beneficiary’s account.”

Sources said that with this many families who are workless and whose survival is at stake will be benefitted.

The Cabinet also decided that for the month of April and May such families who have not applied for ration cards or such families whose ration card is under process will get 10 kg of rice for two months.

The number of such families is 699443 and the state government for this today earmarked Rs 36 crore.

The Cabinet also decided that these families will also get 1 kg of salt for two months and the State cabinet for this earmarked Rs 10 crore.

In today’s Cabinet meeting decision to nine agendas were given approval. Apart from decision related to Covid19 pandemic, the State cabinet also gave its nod declaring seven districts as drought affected districts.

These seven districts are Bokaro, Chatra, Pakur, Godda, Giridih, Hazaribag and Deoghar. 55 blocks of these seven districts have been declared as drought hit. In these districts against the annual rainfall of 530 mm, 333 mm rainfall was recorded last year.

However, in disappointment to RJD leadership no decision was taken on RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s parole, who is languishing in jail on multi crore fodder scam. Lalu on medical ground in admitted at RIMS paying ward.

Sources said that as patients suffering from coronavirus treatment is going on at RIMS, it was speculated that State cabinet will take a decision on release of Lalu on parole ground.

Title: ABVP in U’khand starts blood donation drive
Article:
In view of the acute shortage of blood in all the blood banks of the state, the student wing of BJP, the Akhil Bharatiya Vidhyarthi Parishad (ABVP) has decided to that its members would donate blood in all the hospitals of the state.

As part of the campaign, the ABVP activists voluntarily donated blood at the blood bank of Government Doon Medical College (GDMC) hospital on Monday. A total of 18 units of blood was collected by the blood bank of the biggest hospital of the state on the day.

Due to lock-down enforced in the state contain the infection of the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19), the collection of blood in all the blood banks of the state has got hampered. The president of the state unit of ABVP, Kaushal Kumar said that ABBP members would donate blood in all districts and the organisation is ready for any kind of help . He said that ABVP is helping people during this tough time when the COVID-19 pandemic has hit the country. Member of ABVP national executive, Vikram Pharswan said ABVP has donated 60 units of blood in different hospitals of the state in last two days.

It is pertinent to mention here that due to the lock-down, the blood banks are not able to organise donation camps and the voluntary donors are not reaching out due to the restrictions. In all the blood banks the daily collection of blood has reduced to more than half. Apart from operations, blood is in high demand in the GDMC hospital as large number of Thalassaemia patients are administered blood in the hospital.

These patients are needed to be administered blood at regular intervals to save their lives. The hospital authorities have already issued an appeal to the people to come forward for voluntary donations. It has released phone numbers 0135-2719809 and 7818828263 to assist those who want to donate blood.

Title: 4,76,931 houses to be screened; focus on persons with travel history
Article:
In yet another move to identify people with travel history either from overseas or domestic, East Singhbhum district administration has decided to cover all the houses in the district.

Taking help from the 2011 census, East Singhbhum has identified over 4,76,931 houses in the 11 blocks of the districts (including the urban Jamshedpur-Jugsalai block) and reach out to each of the houses. For this it has mobilised not only the over 1700 sahiyas and anganbari sevikas and also the 1885 booth level officers (entrusted after polling booths during election), panchayat raj institutions and even thana-level community leaders.

“We are taking every step to ensure that people having travel history are covered. We want to to screen every individual who might have come from abroad or from another state or district to East Singhbhum and want to reach each of the houses in urban and rural areas of the district in a limited time span. We have decided to involve everyone entrusted with implementation of government schemes and activities in the exercise and want to complete it within a week,” said East Singhbhum deputy commissioner Ravi Shankar Shukla.

The booth level officers training were held this morning at different locations of the district. Sawant appealed to the people to cooperate with the survey team, and requested them to provide all details, including of people living in rented accomodation. “We have prepared a community survey questionnaire on Covid-19,” he said. After the survey reports are filed, booths will prepare a history sheet and send it to the primary health centre (PHC) concerned.

The administration has formed teams at block-level and also in three civic bodies of Jamshedpur, Jugsalai and Mango for house-to-house search within three km radius area for Covid-19 positive cases.

An official informed that separate teams have been formed in Mango, Jamshedpur and Jugsalai and also in remaining 10 blocks of the districts which will help the district surveillance in monitoring those undergoing quarantine at state centre’s or at homes and will also undertake house-to-house search if there is a positive case.

The team will focus on people having travel history. Special attention will be given to the elderly, pregnant women and those with co-morbid conditions such as diabetes, hypertension and low immunity.

“Movement of people has been limited to emergency and essential services to contain the possible spread of the coronavirus. In effect, it means citizens cannot come out of their homes and move around in public places unless they have an emergency to explain.

We had been requesting and advising people to stay indoors. But for the first time in years, the entire city is witnessing a lockdown and authorities can prosecute those found violating the order,” said an official.

City police have deployed a large force of officers at earmarked crossings to check the movement of vehicles. Multiple teams are patrolling the city to ensure people stay indoors.

Title: Bundles of currency notes on roads frighten people
Article:
Scattered currency notes of Rs 10 denomination created panic among the villagers on NH 75 near Lagma village under Garhwa police station on Monday.

10 bundles of currency notes were found lying on the road today and the residents called the police, which called to the medical team for seizing the notes after sanitising them. The local people insisted that the notes had been thrown on the road to spread coronavirus.

"The notes, seized by the medical team after sanitising them, were kept separately," said Civil Surgeon NK Rajak said notes will keep separately for 24 hours."

The residents of the near by villages, meanwhile, remained locked in discussion.

The residents, while maintaining social distancing, discussed the 'threat of corona through currency notes' till the police asked them to return to their homes.

In normal times, the notes would not have remained on the road for long. Any passersby would have quietly picked up the same and walked away without a word.

According to the thana in-charge Ramod Singh "Prima facie it seems that someone must have been taking the note from the bank and it has fallen," we are making contact with all the banks that who withdrawn this note, Singh added.

Title: 2 new corona cases found in Bokaro, district count reaches 8
Article:
Bokaro has become another coronavirus hotspots after Hindipidi in Ranchi as the district reported two new positive cases in the last 48 hours, taking the total number of COVID-19 cases to eight.

The new COVID-19 positive patients are a 65-year-old person and his son (40), resident of Chatniabagi Tola of Sadam Village under Gomia block of the district; both have a contact history, said A K Pathak Civil Surgeon Bokaro.

“They are close kin of the man (72) who recently died (on 8 April) due to COVID-19 infection. They were in the probable list and were at high risk of infection,” added Pathak.

We are tracing their contacts and have sent our team to collect samples of the villagers too, he said.

A total of 197 samples have been sent for investigations and till now eight persons were tested positive with COVID-19 infection. We are waiting for 60 more reports; the reports will reveal the stage of the spread of Coronavirus infection in Bokaro, said Civil Surgeon.

In the second phase, all total 49 samples (including four BGH doctors) were sent for investigation, out of which 47 reported negative. Few of the reports we have received in late-night while few were received on today morning, said Mukesh Kumar Deputy Commissioner Bokaro.

Both positive cases are from Chatniabagi Tola of Sadam village under the Gomia block. The village has been completely sealed and the entry of outsiders are banned, said Kumar adding “At least 40 CCTV cameras have been installed to monitor the people so that people do not come out of the house unnecessarily as well as strictly follow the lockdown.”

Telo and Pipradih villages under Chandrapura block were also sealed; CCTV cameras have been installed for monitoring of both villages so that surveillance can be done strictly, he said.

The first positive case of coronavirus infection a woman of Telo village has been reported in the Bokaro district on 5 April. She hid the information that she along with five other family members have participated in the Jamaat congregation at Nizamuddin Markaz in Delhi. Later on 8 April, her three family members (two woman's granddaughters and one is her brother-in-law) also tested positive. They are on isolation at BGH now.

Again on 10 April, a 33-year youth, resident of Telo village was tested positive. The youth was come in contact with the woman who tested positive for COVID-19 on 5 April. The person of Sadam village who died due to COVID-19 infection also has a contact history with the participants who returned from the Jamaat congregation.

Meanwhile Bokaro DC appealed to masses, to strictly follow the lockdown. Be safe in your own homes. “There is no need to be panic,” he urged. Do not post any rumor like post related with coronavirus on social media otherwise drastic action will be taken,” said the DC.

Title: 53 samples so far tested coronavirus -ve in Palamu
Article:
Fifty three samples out of 134 sent to RIMS Ranchi for coronavirus test has come negative till April 12 said civil surgeon Palamu John F Kennedy.

Kennedy said, “On an average we get test report a dozen from Ranchi and all have so far till April 12 remained negative.” However, he said there is no room for complacency and people must adhere to social distancing and must also reveal their travel history which if hidden for no gain proves too dangerous.

Kennedy said around 2,300 sahiyyas are moving house to house taking notes of travel history of family members. Each sahiyya is to do at least 50 house a day by noting down details of travel history.

The Civil surgeon has asked people to co operate with sahiyyas when they reach their houses as any hiding of travel history or sickness whatsoever it may be may prove too bad for everyone.

These ground health work force is knocking at doors to find out who the latest is to join the family after any jaunt outside homes beit outside district, state etc.

Kennedy said health workers face resistance when people are asked to undergo institutional quarantine. Home quarantine they do not resent much but when it comes to institutional quarantine which is a government quarantine they react and resist said civil surgeon.

On Sunday three boys came from Kota to Daltonganj by car, who were given institutional quarantine at one of the schools here but here too their parents wanted them to be with the families which health team declined to oblige said Kennedy.

Title: Lockdown: PMJDY beneficiaries flout norms of social distancing
Article:
The beneficiaries of Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojana account holders are flouting norms for social distancing in view of coronavirus. Long queues of people can be seen at the banks to take the amount being disbursed.

Meanwhile, the East Singhbhum district administration has decided to ask the bank management for introducing banking correspondence and ensure the beneficiaries Rs 500 at their door step.

As per a central government's step in providing monetary relief to women Jandhan account holders, Rs 500 is to be deposited in each of their accounts for three successive months. The step was taken to give monetary support to the women belonging to the below poverty line (BPL) categories who have been hit amid the ongoing lockdown due to the coronavirus menace.

The beneficiaries who hail mostly from slum areas do not wear masks nor maintain the social distancing while standing in queues for getting Rs 500. The crowd of Jandhan account holders can be seen in the banks located in the localities at Karandih, Mango, Baridih, Parsudih, Jugsalai, Bagbera, and Sonari

For getting the Rs 500, a beneficiary has to obtain a form, then submit it for getting a token from the bank concerned.

Though East Singhbhum district administration had ordered banks to enforce social distancing during crowding by beneficiaries of jan dhan yojana but the banks have failed to ensure the implementation of the directives.

According to Indian Banks’ Association (IBA) directive banks have started depositing Rs 500 per month into jan dhan yojana accounts held by women.

A senior official of State Bank of India said that all banks have been asked to click pictures of beneficiaries and send it to their zonal office as proof of adherence to social distancing during banking hours (between 10 am and 4 pm).

“ We have been directed to ensure that social distancing is maintained. The banks have been directed to ensure strict compliance of social distance (at least a meter distance) amongst beneficiaries of the scheme, click pictures at different points of time and send it to their zonal office. We have also asked all banks to keep enough stock of hand sanitisers at the entry point of the banks in view of the Covid-19 pandemic,” said the official.

Title: Inbrief
Article:
BSL Group Accident Insurance renewal

A tender process was adopted to continue the insurance coverage for the year 2020-21 (16.05.2020 to 15.05.2021) of Bokaro Steel Group Accident Insurance Committee. The insurance policy has been given to Reliance General Insurance Company Limited due to the lowest rate of Reliance General Insurance Company Limited in the tender process. The insurance premium for each employee is 25,00,000 the insurance premium will be Rs 2993. It may be noted that the insurance premium was Rs 246.75 per sum insured last year for Rs1,00,000, which will be reduced to Rs 119.72 per Rs 100,000 per year.If an employee has a disability or death due to accident, the information is to be submitted to the Secretary of the Committee within 25 days of the accident in writing in the prescribed form forwarded by the departmental officer.

Tales of Happiness spreads positivity

There is a unique initiative by the district administration, Bokaro at the time of this lock down due to COVID 19 epidemic. Through live programme, an attempt was made to create an entertainment atmosphere among the common people. Under this programme scholars getting called subject wise every day and their experiences will be spread through Facebook Live to spread positive message among the public. Through this knowledge science, Panchatantra story, Nana - Nani , Dada - Dadi story, Motivational, song music, poetry etc will be broadcast live. In this series today teacher of DPS Mahashweta tried to make everyone's mind entertained with her poetry and ghazals. DPRO Bokaro Rahul presented a sanitizer made by the district administration as a welcome kit and extended thanks with best wishes to the teacher for showing her gesture during this crisis.

Free meals for rural masses

Research Scholar & Activist, Avanendra Prataap, has been distributing meals and cleanliness items in semi rural areas for those who are facing unfortunate events during the lock down.

Recently he conducted a Food campaign programme in Misir Gonda, alias Pahara Gonda village, block tehsil Kanke, Ranchi. In addition, he also urged the government bodies to give proper awareness, Sanitizers, mask/glove items & other facilities to the underprivileged people in view of corona pandemic.

Title: Small grocery shop owners feel effect of supply bottleneck
Article:
Local grocery shop owners are facing a problems to meet consumers demand as supply of several essential things are running low due to ongoing lockdown announced by the Government.

The shop owners are saying that it is tough time to fulfill consumers’ demand as most of the grocery shop items are running short of supply due scarcity of transportation system and other reasons like irregular schedule of wholesale markets.

The Government had announced that all supermarkets would be closed during lockdown to create congestion free environment, which will help to fight against spread of Corona virus.

Though Ranchi District Administration assured the people that there will not be scarcity of essential commodities in the market due to lockdown but due to closure of supermarkets like Big Bazar, Reliance Smart and others, the people of cities like Ranchi, Jamshedpur, Dhanbad, Bokaro and Hazaribagh are become dependent on local grocery shops as a large number of people living in these cities were buying their grocery items from these supermarkets.

Pandra Krisi Bazar Samiti is one of the biggest wholesale markets of the State for grocery items and food grains but at present it is witnessing less footfalls than before announcement of lockdown.

A local grocery shop owner at Gandhinagar of Kanke Road, Vinod Gupta said that there is huge scarcity of grocery items in the wholesale market due to scarcity of supply. "Due to closure of supermarkets now most of the customers are coming at local grocery shops but we are not able to meet their demand due to scarcity of the items. The Government has provided online facility system for those consumers who used to buy from supermarkets," he added.

"Scarcity of transportation have caused the supply bottleneck of grocery items and another big reason is irregular functioning of wholesale market as most of the grocery items wholesalers are not opening their shops as earlier," said Gupta.

A wholesaler at Pandra Krishi Bazar Samiti, Vinay Aggarwal said that there is scarcity of food grains and other grocery items in the wholesale market due to lack of transportation.

"The transporters also want to be safe from the epidemic so in this period they are not running their trucks. The epidemic also created panic among wholesalers as many of them are not opening their shops due to fear", he added.

Title: Odd-even rule in mandis to restrict footfall
Article:
Concerned about coronavirus threat in crowed areas, Development Minister Gopal Rai on Monday chaired a meeting with the market associations of seven wholesale markets to ensure social

distancing. Various decisions, including implementation of odd - even and market timings, entry with coupons were taken, said an official.

For better crowd management ensuring distancing amid corona spread, the Delhi Government has formulated four special task forces and seven task forces under the Vice-Chairperson and Development secretary of the Delhi Agricultural Market Board will ensure implementation of Government orders in these markets.

“There are seven mandis in Delhi, five are of fruit, vegetables, fish and poultry items and two (Najafgarh and Narela) are specifically for vegetables. Now, the crops have started coming, therefore, all the mandis have become pro-active to maintain proper supply in the Capital. There were issues regarding social distancing in these wholesale markets, therefore, today I held a meeting with the market associations. The Delhi Government has implemented an odd-even policy in these markets to restrict the footfall.

Title: Muslim vegetable vendor abused, thrashed, one held
Article:
The Delhi Police on Monday arrested a man for abusing and thrashing a young vegetable seller with a wooden stick in southeast Delhi. The incident occurred on April 10.

A video of the incident also went viral on social media. In the video, the accused identified as Praveen Babbar, a resident of Badarpur Extension, is seen asking the vegetable seller to show his identity card but he could not. The man then angrily asks him his name and address. When the vegetable seller identifies himself as Mohammad Saleem, the man abuses him and beats him. He also threatens him to not come in the locality without an ID.

According to R P Meena, the Deputy Commissioner of Police (DCP), Southeast district, a twitter message was received from Cyber Cell in which one person seen asking the name and address of a vegetable seller and later beating him with stick.

“Enquiry was made into the matter and a bike seen in the video was traced in the name of Sudhanshu, a resident of Uttar Pradesh Moradabad area. On asking him about the incident, he informed that this incident happened at Tajpur Road and he identified the person who hit the vegetable seller as Praveen Babbar,” said the DCP.

“Praveen runs a shop of tour and travels. On enquiry, he stated that on the day of incident, there were about 10 vegetable sellers rehris at the site and he had asked the vegetable seller to move from there as lockdown had been enforced but he didn't move following which he got angry and thrashed the victim,” said the DCP.

“Victim has also been traced and he stated that on April 10 at around 1:30 PM when he was at Tajpur road, Praveen abused and beat him with a stick. A case was registered against Babbar under IPC sections153 (wantonly giving provocation with intent to cause riot), 355 (assault with intent to dishonour person), 298 (uttering words with deliberate intent to wound the religious feelings of any person) and 323 (voluntarily cashing hurt) at Badarpur police station. Praveen Babbar has been arrested in this regard,” the DCP added.

Title: G’gram gets ‘movement pass’ via GMDA mobile app
Article:
Amid lockdown across the district the Gurugram Metropolitan Development Authority (GMDA) has developed a mobile phone app named “Movement Pass” so that the residents of the city can obtain official permission to step out of their homes for essential supplies.

For this, the residents can approach GMDA’s Mobile app where the Movement pass can be applied through online process and with requisite documents and reason and after approval, the Movement Pass will be issued electronically with a QR code.

Also, the copy of the issued pass will be sent to the applicant’s mobile as well as email ID.

According to a data provided by the development authority, till date, nearly 20,604 requests for Movement Pass were received and 6,953 are issued after scrutiny of documents submitted and reasons indicated by the applicants.

Apart from this, the department’s mobile app is also providing information related to the Covid-19 epidemic across the state.

“Mobile App is a useful Integrated one-point Informative solution for citizens of Gurugram to connect with administration, access govt services, make utility payments, has special enablers during Covid-19 virus and Smart Solutions etc. We request the citizens to use it to the maximum,” said Sonal Goel, additional CEO of GMDA.

Goel also informed that the residents of the Gurugram district can avail several facilities related to the coronavirus problem, including Government notifications, information about hospitals, pharmacy, Test Centres and Isolation Centres for COVID-19 patients through this app.

The officials also said that via the App, people can get several other facilities like complaints about water, sewer, meter, drainage, lighting, parking, waterlogging, city bus location and road information etc.

Title: Govt starts disinfection drive with hi-tech machines
Article:
The Delhi Government on Monday started disinfection drive with hi- tech Japanese machines under its operation - SHIELD to stop spread of COVID -19.

Started from Rajinder Nagar, the disinfection drive is aimed at preventing the spread of coronavirus and high-risk zones ascertained by the health department. The machines procured by the Delhi government has can disinfect up to 20,000 square meters.

Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal announced on Sunday that hi-tech Japanese technology will be used by the Delhi Government to prevent the further spread of the deadly virus and disinfection drive will be carried out at red and orange zones of the National Capital. This is the first time in India that such a technology is being used to tackle the Covid-19 pandemic.

“To tackle the coronavirus outbreak the Delhi Government has marked various containment zones and divided them into red and orange zones. The disinfection drive will start at the red and orange zones. This Japanese technology is very unique and it is made specifically to spray disinfectants. This technology is also very flexible as its length is adjustable, therefore, it can easily enter narrow lanes along with the broader areas," said Rajinder Nagar MLA Raghav Chadha.

He added the farmers use these machines to spray disinfectants at the farmlands, therefore, these are specifically equipped for disinfection and sanitization works. The chemical composition used for the disinfection drive as per the guidelines of WHO. These machines spray the disinfectants in a way that can kill the germs and virus at any solid surface.

"The key target of the Delhi government is to focus on the containment zones, therefore, the disinfection drive will start with the red zones. At Rajinder Nagar Vidhan Sabha we have started a pilot project with three such machines in presence of the experts to analyse the performance and results thereof. We have sanitised the whole area and studied all the necessary parameters. After a careful consultation with the experts, it has been decided that this is a fully equipped technology, and the disinfection drive should immediately start at the containment zones," said Chadha.

Chadha Tweeted, "Did a pilot with hi-tech Japanese spray machines equipped with ability to disinfect & sanitize large areas upto 20,000 sq mtrs an hour, under the "Mukhyamantri Delhi Sanitization Drive. Rajinder Nagar Constituency sanitized by these machines using micro atomized disinfectant."

Title: DMRC senior officials resume work from office
Article:
The senior officials of Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC), including its Managing Director Dr Mangu Singh resumed work from office on Monday. However, passenger services continue to remain closed as part of the nationwide lockdown to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.

The DMRC also conducted all meetings via video conference to discuss a range of important issues and webinars, online courses are being made available to the employees for their knowledge and awareness enhancement.

On the project front, DMRC’s team of architects and designers are regularly coordinating with site personnel, design consultants and contractors to finalise all the designs for the ensuing construction work of Phase 4, SDMC said in a statement.

“Building Information Modeling’ (BIM), an online mechanism has been devised through which designs, drawings and 3d models can be uploaded online. Officers can leave their comments and observations through the same software and no hard copy or print out is necessary,” it said.

Senior officers are taking frequent meetings with the architects, engineers, contractors etc via video conference, it said, adding that the engineers deputed at the sites are also regularly conducting meetings through video conference to deliberate on a range of issues, which would be encountered once the construction work starts.

“Issues such as design submission and finalization, procurement orders by contractors, manpower deployment at sites etc are being dealt with. Daily project Reports (DPR) is being prepared to keep a tab on the overall progress made,” it added.

The safety department is organising frequent webinars for project engineers on various aspects of construction site safety. “Five webinars have already been organised and another two are planned this week. More than 400 engineers across the DMRC hierarchy are attending these webinars,” it said.

Title: Child pornography demand spiked since lockdown: ICPF
Article:
Following the 21-day lockdown across the country in wake of coronavirus outbreak, there has been alarming rise in demand for child pornography material, said India Child Protection Fund (ICPF) on Monday. The report has been submitted to the Women & Child Development ministry for further action.

According to Nivedita Ahuja, the spokesperson, ICPF, since the lockdown, online data monitoring websites are showing an increase in demand for searches like ‘child porn’, ‘sexy child’ and ‘teen sex videos’.

“This is a blatant violation of the directions of the Supreme Court, and a violation of national policy. Pornographic websites are playing hide-and-seek with Indian law and judiciary by simply changing their website URLs. The Government of India must urgently crackdown on child pornography and also initiate a global dialogue for an international convention against child sexual abuse material,” she said.

ICPF has released a report titled ‘Child Sexual Abuse Material in India’, a research of child pornography demand in 100 cities in India like New Delhi, Chennai, Mumbai, Kolkata, Bhubaneswar and Indore.

As per report, the overall demand for child pornography was an average of 5 million per month in 100 cities on the public web during December 2019, which has now spiked. The report reveals up to 200 per cent increase in demand for violent content which shows children “choking”, “bleeding” and “tortured”.

“This suggests that “Indian men are not ‘satisfied’ with generic child pornography and demand violent and exploitative content,” said the spokesperson.

“Metro cities like New Delhi, Kolkata, Chennai and Mumbai, besides many Tier II and capital cities, which are seeing a sharp increase in Coronavirus cases, have been red-flagged by the December study as hotspots for child pornography. The organisation has implored authorities to further step up online vigil in these cities for potential exploiters,” said the spokesperson.

ICPF has also warned that the alarming rise indicates millions of paedophiles, child rapists and child pornography addicts have migrated online, making the internet extremely unsafe for children. “Without stringent action, this could result in a drastic rise in sexual crimes against children,” the spokesperson further added. When asked about increased traffic about child pornography, a senior Delhi Police official said that they haven't reviewed the report yet. Delhi Police cyber cell keeps an eye on such predators as they pose risk to children, the official added.

Title: Most patients in Assam fine, to be discharged soon
Article:
Most of the 30 Covid-19 patients in Assam are recovering and their discharge from hospitals is expected to start on Wednesday.

"Most patients, earlier infected by nCoV, are either stable or good. If everything remains fine, their discharge is likely to start from April 15," said Assam Health and Family Welfare Minister Himanta Biswa Sarma, here on Monday.

Addressing the media, he said, "Of the 3,209 swab samples collected, 3,070 were found negative. Of the 1,421 samples of Tablighi Jamaat meet participants, 29 tested positive and 1,358 negative. Test report of 34 samples are awaited."

Two more coronavirus cases - a 35-year-old man from Assam and a 33-year-old man from Nagaland -- were reported in Assam on Monday.

The Minister said a person from Dhubri (western Assam), linked with the Tablighi Jamaat meet at Nizamuddin Markaz (in Delhi), has been found coronavirus positive.

A private hospital in Dimapur (Nagaland) referred a patient to the GMCH (Guwahati Medical College and Hospital). He tested positive and was undergoing treatment at the GMCH, he said.

The man from Nagaland had travelled from Kolkata to Dimapur on March 24 and when he developed symptoms of nCoV, he was shifted to GMCH on April 5.

Of the 37 positive cases in five northeastern states -- Assam (31), Manipur (2), Tripura (2), Mizoram (1) and Arunachal Pradesh (1) -- 30 had attended the Jamaat meet.

According to the Assam Minister, the state reported its first coronavirus death in Hailakandi district on April 10. The Covid-19 death in Assam was also the first in the northeast.

Title: More than 19 lakh women receive Rs 500 through PMJDY
Article:
More than 19 lakhs women account holders under Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojna (PMJDY) have received Rs 500 each till Monday out of total of 73 lakh women account holders in the State.

In an attempt to provide relief during ongoing lockdown to poor and needy among women the Center Government had announced that women account holder under PMJDY would get Rs 500 per month for three months in their accounts from the month of April to meet their essential requirements during the ongoing lockdown. There is a total of 1.33 crore bank account holders in the State under PMJDY scheme, out of which 73 lakh are women account holders.

State Level Bankers’ Committee, Deputy General Manager, Sanjib Sarkar said that in order to help fight against the global epidemic COVID-19, the Central Government launched the 'Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Yojana' (PMGKY) for the poor. He said that till Monday more than 19 lakh women account holders have withdrawn Rs 500 for the month of April in the State and at an average of two lakh account holders per day withdrawing their money from the banks.

"Under this scheme, the account holder under PMJDY will get Rs 500 in their bank account every month for the next three months for the women account holders. The amount will be distributed by the Central Government, so that the women account holder could not face difficulties in purchasing the necessary thins and other requirements," Sarkar said.

“Keeping in mind the transition of Corona virus, the SLBC had issued appropriate guidelines for all the banks, payment banks, small finance banks and LDMs in the State to ensure smooth withdrawal of money with following guidelines of social distance of PMJDY women account holders, all account holders have been separated on the basis of the last digit of their account number.

"Separate days have been set for women account holders of PMJDY to ensure that bank branches, should not be over crowded and people maintain social distance. All the account holders have been requested by the State Government and SLBC to withdraw the above amount only when required and other alternative means such as Bank Mitra and ATMs should be used more," said Sarkar.

Title: No relation between rising temp, Covid-19 spread: Doctors
Article:
With the mercury levels gradually increasing, medical officials claim that there is no established relation between the variations in temperature and the spread of Coronavirus.

Officials also state that the disease COVID-19 which is currently present across the globe is affecting humans in varying local climates. The exact temperature to deactivate the virus is still unknown.

“The hypothesis that rising temperatures will kill the virus has failed. In some states across India where the temperature is being recorded at above 40 degree Celsius, COVID-19 is still prevalent. There are many viruses which are temperature sensitive like influenza. But probably Coronavirus is not so. Although the number of cases in India is less compared to the other countries but the temperature theory is still not valid,” said Deputy Chief Medical Officer (CMO) CCL Hospital, Dr Rajkumar.

Dr Rajkumar further stated that with Coronavirus spreading people should keep themselves hydrated during the summer months. “If an infected person gets dehydrated then the chances of complications increase. The virus spreads through human contact so social distancing and hand hygiene needs to be maintained. Till the time a vaccine is not developed for this virus, social distancing and isolation are the only medications. For all messages on social media suggesting the intake of malaria medicines, lemon juice and the likes, it has not been proven that any such thing can reduce the chances of contracting the infection.”

The frequency of almost all infectious diseases reduces in the summer season but the same cannot be stated for COVID-19.

“It has been observed that Coronavirus has been equally effective in cold as well as torrid countries. The infectivity rate has been constant so it cannot be established that it will reduce in summers. As compared to winter or rainy season, the incidents of all communicable diseases generally reduce in summers but the same cannot be stamped for COVID-19. A reduction in the number of cases can be expected but it cannot be said that the gross incidents of infection is low in summers,” said Dr SS Harsh, CMO, Central Government Health Services. He further emphasised that viruses are very sensitive particles outside the human body and can be easily destroyed with soap water and disinfectants like alcohol. The guidelines set by the government need to be strictly adhered to.

Title: PM Modi extends birthday greetings to Guv Tandon
Article:
President Ramnath Kovind and Prime Minister Narendra Modihave extended birthday greetings to the Governor Lalji Tandon.

The Vice President M Venkaiah Naidu, Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan, former Chief Minister Kamal Nath, Union Ministers Rajnath Singh and Shri Narendra Singh Tomar, Governors, Chief Ministers and Deputy Chief Ministers of various other states and dignitaries greeted Shri Tandon through email and on Twitter and phone.

Governor Tandon is constantly receiving greetings through e-mails,

Twitter and telephone from various sections of the society, religious leaders, social service organisations, scholars, litterateurs, journalists and general public for long and healthy life.

Title: IGRMS to hold online lecture on Democracy and the Ideal of fraternity: Lesson for India
Article:
To observe the 129th birth anniversary of BR Ambedkar, Indira Gandhi Rashtriya Manav Sanghralaya (IGRMS) will organise an online lecture on Democracy and the Ideal of fraternity: Lesson for India after Corona Pandemic. The online lecture will be held on Tuesday at 11:30 am.

There will be live streaming of the lecture on the Facebook handle of IGRMS. The lecture will be delivered by Dilip Singh (ITS), Joint Director Administration and Security, IGRMS.

The online lecture will be held under the popular lecture series of IGRMS which is organized on a regular basis. With the current situation of lockdown due to pandemic Coronavirus, the lecture series will be held online.While informing about the online lecture, Public Relation Officer (PRO), IGRMS Ashok Kumar Sharma said that the online lecture is organized keeping in view the current situation of the world. He said, “These days everyone is seen doing something or the other on their mobile phones. So, we thought why not to do an online lecture series wherein the people can attend an event on their mobile phones.”

He further said that the entire lecture will have live streaming on Facebook and anyone can attend it. “People are so much into coronavirus news updates that there is no room left for them to think something else. This online event will surely divert their mind,” he added.

Besides, Sharma informed that the people who are associated with IGRMS from across the world have been sent an invite for the lecture. Also, this lecture will be recorded for those who cannot attend the live streaming.

Title: Indore awaits reports of 1,300 samples in 48 hrs
Article:
With 328 positive cases including 36 deaths; Indore in Madhya Pradesh is narrating a terrifying tale of covid19 assault and the city has geared up for a bigger challenge as reports of over 1,300 samples is expected to be received in next 48 hours.

Total 1,142 samples have been flown to New Delhi-based labs in a State plane on Sunday. Around 200 (daily testing capacity in Indore) samples are being tested in city lab. The seats were removed from the plane to accommodate sample boxes. The same flight is expected to bring medicines from Delhi.

Administration in Indore has claimed that portion of these reports could be received on Monday and rest of them could be clear on Tuesday.

This bulk testing, the administration is claiming, will end the backlog in the city battered by the fatal virus. As the testing has intensified, the number of positive cases have grown exponentially in the city. To add the city to stat with had minimal testing capacity of testing 40 samples a day which increased by five times recently.

However, with administration rounding up suspects in thousands, this has proved negligible.

Reports quoting findings of Rapid Response Team of the Centre had claimed that testing, a vital tool in defeating corona, was delayed by at least 15 days in Indore and the virus had made inroads in the city a fortnight prior to the lockdown announced the Centre.

The central team which had visited the city in March found that locals had contracted the disease between March 8 to 11 but exhibited symptoms from March 14 to 18.

The lockdown was announced on March 23. To add, large numbers of locals had ventured out in celebration mode at two places in the city on March 22 during the Janta Curfew.

Sensing the gravity of the situation, the district administration had clamped curfew in Indore on March 25.

Much to the confusion of health authorities, the physicians have failed to detect the source of infection among large numbers of positive cases.

Scores of areas have been declared containment zones in the city while suspects are kept at around a dozen places identified for the purpose.

Around 250 teams of Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA), aganwadi workers and teachers have surveyed around 16,000 homes and detected 250 people with suspected symptoms and barring 27 suspects who had mild cough, remaining have been quarantined.

Total availability of beds in the state is 29914 including 9492 for isolation and 1598 for ICU. The state has 993 ventilators available, the statement read.

Till April 11, the state has collected 8516 samples out of which 5790 have tested negative and 2197 reports are awaited. A total of 529 tested positive till Saturday which has risen to 604 on Monday morning.

In Bhopal, 140 have tested positive till now including three deaths and three others who have recovered completely.

Title: Sisodia inspects Op SHIELD execution
Article:
Delhi Deputy Chief Minister Manish Sisodia on Monday visited various Assembly constituencies and inspected implementation of Operation SHIELD.

Sisodia also inspected food distribution centers and night shelters in the areas. “Today, I inspected night shelters, food distribution and operation SHIELD in Assembly constituencies of Trilokpuri, Laxmi Nagar, Viswas Nagar, Patparganj and Kondli,” he tweeted.

Expressing his happiness over cooperation of public and police, he said the number of infected people from coronavirus is contained in such areas. He said that people are very happy with successful implementation of operation SHIELD.

Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal has announced a massive sanitisation drive in the Covid-19 affected and high-risk areas, classified as red and orange zones. The number of coronavirus containment zones in Delhi rose to 43 on Sunday.

The operation launched by the AAP Government has been successful in Dilshad Garden in northeast Delhi which was a hotspot until now.

“The gali of Krishna Kunj was sealed here after three people of the same family found coronavirus positive. Beat constables are very active in providing food and medicines with the help of whatsApp groups,” he tweeted in Hindi.

In another tweet, Sisodia said that approx nine lakh people are being served food twice a day. “On the direction of Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal, nine lakh people are being fed twice a day in Delhi Governmnet schools,” he said.

Title: 200 booked, 3,358 detained for violating lockdown orders
Article:
The Delhi Police on Monday registered over 200 cases and detained 3,358 people across the national Capital for violating Government orders during the coronavirus lockdown.

According to the data shared by the police, 201 cases were registered under section 188 (for disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of the Indian Penal Code till 5pm.

Police said that a total of 3,358 people have been detained under section 65 (persons bound to comply with reasonable directions of police officers) and 322 vehicles have been impounded under section 66 of the Delhi Police Act.

“The police also registered 161 cases against people for stepping outside their residence without wearing masks. A total of 544 movement passes have been issued,” police said.

Since March 24, over 78,000 people have been detained so far for violating order under section 65 of the Delhi Police Act.

However, on Monday, Delhi Police received over 800 calls on their 24x7 helpline number to resolve issues related to lockdown. Police said that total 19,11o number of calls received by police till Sunday on their helpline 011-23469526.

“Police received 890 calls from Sunday 2 pm to Monday 2 pm. Out of 890, around 47 calls were related to outside Delhi, which have been referred to respective state helpline numbers. A total of 13 calls were received related to no food/no money, which have been forwarded to NGO for direct relief at their addresses,” said police.

“While three calls were received regarding medical issues and have been resolved through proper guidance to proceed in case of such emergencies while 649 calls were related to movement passes and were advised to apply online on website of Delhi Police,” said police.

The move comes following nationwide restrictions due to complete lockdown imposed across the country to contain coronavirus.

Title: MHA gives third reminder to WB for strict lockdown
Article:
Amid reports of new corona infections in some medical facilities leading to partial shutting down of at least two more hospitals, including the Calcutta Medical College Hospital, in Kolkata the Central Government has dashed off yet another letter to the State Government asking it to impose lockdown restriction in proper manner.

The letter, third in row from the Union Home Ministry has ‘requested” the State to “take necessary action in order to ensure strict adherence to lockdown measures. District authorities and field agencies may accordingly be directed so as to prevent any such recurrence in future,” State officials said.

Pointing out deficiencies towards “strict adherence” of the lockdown measures the letter has said how there large assemblies of people were being allowed “in establishments dispensing essential commodities.”

The MHA has also referred to reports of how “shops dealing with non-essential commodities were allowed to remain open in Siliguri.” It has further pointed out how “the lockdown was violated in some mosques in Murshidabad district.”

While the latest letter sent by a Deputy Secretary to Bengal Chief Secretary and Director General of Police was summarily dismissed as a “routine exchange,” Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee had on Saturday reacted sharply saying “you all know by mentioning the areas where the lockdown is allegedly not being implemented properly Delhi wants to pinpoint a particular group of population … But I want to tell them that we are fighting against a deadly virus and not a communal virus. I will not allow any communal politics here.”

The letter comes amid reports that the State Government was strictly implementing the wearing of masks, particularly in Kolkata. The citizens who were seen moving around without masks were either sent back home or forced to purchase masks from medical shops sources said.

Meanwhile, two medical facilities including the Gynaecology department of the Calcutta Medical College Hospital and the Charnock Hospital were closed down following report of corona infection among some patients, sources said. At least 50 doctors and nursing staff of the stated department have been sent to quarantine sources said.

Earlier two nursing homes at Park Circus and some departments of RG Kar Medical College and NRS College were closed down and their medical staff were sent to compulsory quarantine following reports of corona infections.

The latest infections took the total number of corona cases in Bengal to 122, sources said adding 7 patients had died due the disease --- with two deaths reported in last 24 hours. Health Department sources said there were “95 active corona cases in Bengal as of now.”

Title: Sena slams Fadnavis for safe passage of Wadhawans
Article:
Dubbing IAS officer Amitabh Gupta’s decision to give “safe passage” to scam accused Wadhawan brothers and 21 other family members to Mahabaleshwar amid lockdown period as a “conspiracy” to defame the MVA Government, the Shiv Sena on Tuesday said that Gupta had been appointed by the State Principal Secretary (Home) by former chief minister and senior BJP leader Devendra Fadnavis.

Indirectly accusing Fadnavis of behind the “conspiracy” to malign the Uddhav Thackeray government, the Shjiv Sena – in an editorial published its mouth-piece “Saamana” said: “The current leader of the Opposition in the Assembly (Fadnavis) says that Gupta might not have given travel permission to Wadhavans on his own. There must be someone behind it.. Why is he making all kind of baseless allegations?. The Wadhawan incident happened, when the entire Maharashtra government was pre-occupied with waging a war against Coronavirus.

“The IAS officer, who gave the ‘safe passage” to Wadhawan, was reportedly appointed in the Home department during the previous regime by Fadnavis himself. By giving special concessions to the Wadhawans, the same IAS officer has tried to put the state government in an embarrassing situation. That it was Fadnavis who had reportedly handpicked and appointed as Principal Secretary (Home) explains who must have been behind the IAS officer concerned who asked him to give travel permission to Wadhavans,” the Saamana editorial said.

“We are pretty sure that a conspiracy was hatched to defame MVA government. If the state government were to help out Wadhawans, then why did the Satara district officials apprehend them and put them under quarantine in Mahabaleshwar? Why did the Satara district (in which Mahabaleshwar falls) ignore the travel permission letter given by Gupta and act legally against them?,” the editorial said.

“The Maharashtra government has sent Gupta on compulsory leave. Since he is an Indian Administrative Officer, it is for the Centre to initiate further action against Gupta. One should ask the Centre as to what action it will take against Gupta and who was actually prompted him to issue to travel permission to the Principal Secretary (Home),” the Saamana said.

It may be recalled that on April 10, the Maharashtra government sent Principal Secretary (Home) Amitabh Gupta on ‘compulsory leave’ for allowing the scam-tainted Wadhawan brothers and their family members to travel from Khandala to Mahabaleshwar on Wednesday during the ongoing lockdown period.

The State government instituted an inquiry against Gupta under Additional chief Secretary (Finance) Additional Chief Secretary Manoj Sonic it also registered an offence under sections 188, 269, 270, 34 of IPC and section 51 (B)of Disaster Management Act and section 11 of Maharashtra Covid-19 Regulations”.

Twenty three members of Wadhawan family were detained by the police at Panchgani on Thursday night while travelling in five cars from Khandala to another hill station of Mahabaleswar in Satara district of western Maharashtra. They were carrying with them a “To whomsoever it may concern” issued to them by Gupta on his personal head, permitting the Wadhawans and others to cross from Khandala in Pune to Mahabaleshwar in Satara.

“This is to just inform you that following are well known to me as they are my family friends and travelling from Khandala to Mahabaleshwar for family emergency… Hence you are here by informed through this letter to co-operate with them to reach their destination,” Gupta’s letter

read.

The Saamana editorial said that one hand the ordinary people were adhering to the lockdown norms and staying at home, while on the other there could not be different set of rules to the moneyed people. “This proves that the people are vigilant and the government machinery is not corrupt. If anyone in the government is involved in the Wadhawan safe passage incident, they would have stopped the Satara district officials from taking action against the Wadhawans,” the editorial said.

“The Uddhav Thackeray believes in the rule of law. It treats everyone equally. It does not differentiate between the poor and the rich. The people ( Fadnavis and other BJP leaders) who are speaking out now will shut their mouth, if one goes into the details of the party to which Wadhwans donated money to.

No one should stoop this low to malign the Government,” the Saamana editorial said.

Advocating against indulging in politics during this crucial period, the Saamana editorial said: “There will be lot of time for politics in future. On one day on Saturday, as many as 1000 people tested positive for Coronavirus in the country. The Maharashtra government is waging a war against Coronavirus. The Opposition should not indulge in acts like this”.

Title: SPO martyred in Kishtwar
Article:
Two suspected terrorists attacked a patrolling party, stationed at Tander police picket under the jurisdiction of Dacchan police station of Kishtwar district, with axes and fled away with their service weapons after killing one of them on the spot and seriously injuring other on Monday.

The injured SPO was evacuated by the jawans of the nearby police post and airlifted to Government Medical college hospital in Jammu where he was undergoing treatment till the time of filing the report. Meanwhile, the joint teams of the Special Operations group of Kishtwar police and Army have launched massive manhunt in the area to track down the assailants. According to official sources, one of the suspected terrorist, facing charges of rape, was released on bail barely 20 days ago.

Inspector General of Police, Jammu range, Mukesh Singh also rushed to Kishtwar to supervise the ongoing operations.

Sharing details of the gruesome attack, police spokesman in a statement said, "at around 1.30 p.m police picket Tander Kishtwar reported that two assailants attacked two SPOs namely Pashid Iqbal and Vishal at some distance (about 200/300 metres) from the post Tander Dachhan with axes and seriously injured both of them".

Out of these two, SPO Pashid Iqbal succumbed to his injuries while SPO Vishal Singh was airlifted to GMC, Jammu.

According to police, both the SPO's had gone to the upper area of Tander for patrolling. The assailants have been identified as Basharat Hussain S/O Gh. Qadir Gainoo and Ashiq Hussain S/O Bashir Ahmed both residents of village Tander, Dachhan.

According to police, Ashiq Hussain was involved in case FIR No 06/2018 U/S 363,376 RPC of P/S Dachhan. He went out on bail 20 days back. Former BJP Minister and ex MLA, Kishtwar Sunil Sharma visited GMC, Jammu to meet injured SPO. Sharma told reporters, an attempt is being made since 2018 to revive militancy in the region.

He said, after large number of active militants, involved in killing of BJP leaders and RSS worker and his PSO were neutralised, several active OGW's have been making desperate bids to revive militancy. He said it is for this reason the assailants involved in the attack on SPO's have fled away with their service weapons.

Title: Law invoked for steady supply of medicines
Article:
The National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority (NPPA) has invoked a clause of a legislation that will equip it to issue directions to the manufacturers for regulating distribution of drugs in case of emergency or in case of non-commercial use in public interest with a view to achieve adequate availability of medicines and medical devices.

The move aims to ensure consistent supply of medicines and medical devices in the country which along with other nations is grappling with the deadly Covid-19 pandemic. The virulent pathogen has so far claimed over 350 lives.

A senior official from the national drug price regulator, NPPA said that Para 3 of the DPCO (Drug Price Control Order)-2013 has been invoked.

“Invoking of para 3 of DPCO-2013 will help the drug pricing regulator to resolve issues associated with the availability, supply and shortage of drugs and medical devices.”

He explained, “as per para 3 of DPCO-2013, NPPA may give directions to manufacturers of active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) or bulk drugs or formulations with a view to achieve adequate availability and to regulate the distribution of drugs, in case of emergency..

“… or in circumstances of urgency or in case of non-commercial use in public interest, direct any manufacturer of any APIs or bulk drug or formulation to increase the production and to sell such APIs or bulk drug to such other manufacturer(s) of formulations and to direct formulators to sell the formulations to institutions, hospitals or any agency as the case may be,” the official said.

Title: Aarogya Setu app current fad
Article: Amid coronavirus scare, Aarogya Setu app, a technology initiative taken by the Centre, has found huge takers. So far over 3.5 crore people have downloaded the app. Aarogya Setu app helps significantly in contact tracing and curbing the spread of the dreaded Covid-19 pandemic. It uses location data from persons’ smartphones to tell users if they have been near someone who tested positive for Covid-19, explained an official.

Title: Govt directs States for smooth movement of trucks
Article:
Following the Commerce Ministry’s suggestion for opening the industries, the Union Home Ministry has directed the States to ensure the “smooth movement” of trucks, workers and functioning at warehouses and cold storages.

Union Home Secretary AK Bhalla in his letter to the State authorities said that all trucks should be permitted with the driver carrying valid driving licences. One more person can travel along with the driver.

“Inter-state and intra-state movement of all trucks and other goods / carrier vehicles with one driver and one additional person is allowed as long as the driver is carrying a valid driver’s licence. This is irrespective of the nature of the cargo, whether essential or otherwise.

No further permit or approval would be required. Empty trucks/ goods carriers should also be allowed to operate while on way to pick up goods, or returning after completing a delivery.

Hence, there is no cause to stop empty trucks provided they have valid documents such as driving license & road permit etc.

“Local authorities should actively facilitate the movement of truck drivers and cleaners from their place of residence to location of their trucks. Local authorities should facilitate the easy to and fro movement of workers to workplace and back, in respect of all the permitted industrial/ commercial activities.Railways, Airports, Seaports, and Customs authorities have already been authorised to issue passes for their staff and contractual labour. This may be ensured,” said MHA in statement.

Title: Centre asks sugar mills to surrender ‘sugar quota’
Article:
The Centre on Monday asked sugar mills to surrender the sugar quota which could not be exported by March-end and submit a detailed report by next week.

In a communication to sugar mills, the food ministry also warned that if mills fail to export the quota, they would not be entitled for their claim for their quota of fourth quarter under the MAEQ scheme and also for maintenance of buffer stock.

The Government also gave more time till April 20 for mills to submit the quarterly report of sugar export. Earlier, mills were supposed to submit the report by April 3.

For the current 2019-20 season (October-September), the Government has allowed export of 6 million tonnes of sugar under the Maximum Admissible Export Quantity (MAEQ) scheme to help deal with the surplus sugar. However, some mills have not been able to export their quota.

The Government has reallocated about 6,50,000 tonnes of unexported sugar that was surrendered by mills.

In February, a senior food ministry official had said that total sugar exports could reach 5 million tonnes in the current season on higher global demand. India has exported 3.8 million tonnes of sugar during the 2018-19 marketing year against the mandatory quota of 5 million tonne.

The country's total sugar production is expected to touch 27 million tonnes this year, lower than 33 million tonnes achieved in the past two years.

Title: eNAM going strong despite criticism
Article:
